column21: What is the range of the data set below? 3, 7, 9, 11, 11, 11, 15, 17, 18, 24

column9: In a situation with two players, how do we find the optimal solution?

column21: An opportunity cost that does not require the firm to spend money

column12: Which of the following actions results in piercing the corporate veil?

column15: Yoho Motors files for bankruptcy. The company's creditors then seek payment from the corporation and the shareholders. Why will the creditors NOT be able to recover their debts from the shareholders?
column17: The corporation offers limited liability to its shareholders.
column18: Alisa owns Alright Business Services. It is a corporation, but Alisa does not use the word 'Incorporated' or 'Inc.' anywhere on her correspondence. Alisa is in charge of paying the bills for the business and sometimes writes rent checks out of her personal account. The business is not doing well, and is several months behind on making rent payments. Her landlord sues Alright Business Services and Alisa for the rent. How will the landlord recover the unpaid rent?
column20: Only from Alisa, since she's in charge of the bills.
column21: A corporation's owners are known as _____.
column23: stockholders

column9: Which one of the following is considered a disadvantage of a corporation?
column11: A corporation is more complex and expensive to run.
column12: What is the difference between an S-corporation and a C-corporation?
column14: A C-corporation is subject to double income taxation, while an S-corporation is not.
column15: Tyler is the sole owner and stockholder of the corporation, Tyler's Tires. Two years ago, Tyler's Tires hired Anna as the CEO. If Tyler dies, what happens to Tyler's Tires?
column17: Nothing, it continues to run under the direction of the CEO.
column18: What do you call the documentation that governs the corporation's activities?
column21: What is the primary reason a business would decide to become a corporation over any other form of organization?
column23: It is ideal for those who want a business that is considered a separate entity from its owners.

column9: Bob goes to Susie's General Store which is a Limited Liability Company. While there, something falls off the shelf and hits Bob on the head. Bob wants to pursue legal action. What are Bob's legal options?
column11: Bob can sue Susie for medical bills and damages.
column12: What does someone have to file to form a limited liability company?
column14: Articles of organization
column15: Which of the following is true about a limited liability company?
column17: It has characteristics of both a corporation and a partnership.
column18: What is the best explanation of pass-through taxation?
column20: Both income and losses pass through the entity and are reported on the tax returns of the individual owners
column21: What document is used to govern the operations of a limited liability company?
column23: Operating agreement

column9: What type of partnership offers no protection from personal liability for the partners?
column11: A general partnership
column12: Which of the following is the best explanation of the main difference or differences between a limited partner and a general partner?
column14: General partners manage and are subject to personal liability, while limited partners do not manage and have limited liability.
column15: Which one of the following is the partnership document that governs the rights and responsibilities of the partners?
column17: Partnership agreement
column18: What type of partnership has a general partner who has full liability and a limited partner whose liability is limited to their investment in the partnership?
column21: Which one of the following do LPs, LLPS, and LLLPs have in common but is not a characteristic of a general partnership?
column23: General partnerships do not typically have to register with the state's secretary of state, but the other types of partnerships do have to register.

column9: Which of the following businesses represents a sole proprietorship?
column11: a criminal law firm with multiple senior partners
column12: A sole proprietorship must register with which of the following?
column14: there are no registration requirements
column15: What happens if a sole proprietorship takes on a second owner?
column17: The business ceases to be a sole proprietorship.
column18: How much protection from liability does a sole proprietorship offer?
column20: the greatest protection since the company is separate from the owner
column21: Which of the following describes the income tax treatment for a sole proprietorship?
column23: Income and losses are reported on the owner's personal income tax return.

column9: Why is it a good idea to create a partnership agreement?
column11: ALL are correct.
column12: How are sole proprietorships taxed?
column14: As individuals
column15: What is the most significant risk factor in a sole proprietorship?
column17: Unlimited liability, even for employee actions
column18: How are taxes handled in a partnership form of business ownership?
column20: The business passes its profits and losses to the owners, and they claim the profits and losses on their personal tax return.
column21: Mary and Joanne would like to start their own jewelry business. They do not want to file a bunch of papers, but also do not want to be personally liable for debts incurred by the company. Which form of ownership should they pursue?
column23: LLC

column9: What is the formula to calculate per unit cost in a process costing system?
column11: total expenses incurred in process ÷ total units produced
column12: Why would a company choose a process costing system over a job costing system?
column14: The company manufactures multiple types of products.
column15: How do process costing systems allocate expenses to products?
column17: By adding total costs at each stage of the manufacturing process then dividing these costs by total number of units produced.
column18: What is an example of a direct materials cost?
column21: What types of manufacturing companies would typically use a process costing system?
column23: All of these answers are correct.

column9: What is product costing?
column11: the process of determining business expenses associated with the manufacture of a product
column12: What is manufacturing overhead?
column14: all expenses incurred during the manufacture of a product that cannot be directly allocated to that product
column15: If the cost-pool for labor has a total of $125,000 and the driver for that pool is 45,000 labor-hours, what is the activity-based costing rate for labor?
column18: What is the difference between traditional costing and activity-based costing systems?
column20: Traditional costing uses a single rate to allocate manufacturing overhead to different products, whereas activity-based costing uses cost pools to apply individual rates.
column21: What is a cost pool?
column23: a grouping of individual costs associated with the manufacture of goods

column9: How does marginal cost differ from total cost?
column11: Marginal cost is the cost of producing just one more unit of a good, while total cost is the sum of all costs of production.
column12: A state government offers tax breaks to companies to build factories in their state. If a company takes up this offer and builds a new factory in this state, what will they be reducing?
column14: Economies of scale
column15: Which of the following are economies of scale most dependent on?
column17: Marginal cost
column18: Which company attempted to reduce their fixed costs at the Rouge River plant and ended up with massive marginal costs?
column21: When foreign automakers achieve economies of scale by positioning plants in the United States to avoid tariffs, which kind of costs are they focused on reducing?
column23: Marginal costs

column9: A contract to be completed in the next six months would be considered which of the following?
column11: Part of short-run production.
column12: What is a long-run cost?
column14: A cost pertaining to production following the fulfillment of current contracts.
column15: What is a short-run cost?
column17: A cost incurred while satisfying current contracts.
column18: Accounting software for a bakery is:
column20: Both a fixed and a variable cost.
column21: Transitioning from baking to catering is considered which of the following?
column23: An acquisition.

column9: Why are all costs associated with long-run production considered to be variable?
column11: when looking to the future there is no way to predict how costs will change
column12: Radio Shack is an example of a company doing which of the following?

column15: Long-run production is best defined as which of the following?
column17: a production strategy focusing on business planning beyond current contracts
column18: The Kikkoman company has been successful in business since the 17th Century due to which of the following?
column20: by focusing its goals on quality products that remain true to the brand that was built many years ago

column23: remaining profitable in the future

column9: All of the following affect marginal cost, EXCEPT _____.

column12: If a company is trying to expand operations, which of the following matters most?

column15: If a company is trying to determine whether or not to enter a new sector, which of the following is most important?
column17: Total cost
column18: Sarah owns a factory that produces tin cans. A company puts in an order for twice as many cans as usual, but only for one month. Why might Sarah turn down this order?
column20: To produce more cans, she'll need to raise wages in the factory, which will raise both her total and average costs.
column21: If a company is trying to determine a fair price for its goods, which of the following matters the most?
column23: Cumulative cost

column9: Sarah owns a factory that produces tin cans. A company puts in an order for twice as many cans as usual, but only for one month. Why might Sarah turn down this order?

column14: Total cost
column15: If a company is trying to expand operations, which of the following matters most?
column17: Marginal cost
column18: All of the following affect marginal cost, EXCEPT _____.
column20: rent on the current factory lease
column21: If a company is trying to determine a fair price for its goods, which of the following matters the most?
column23: Cumulative cost

column9: A decrease in average cost by 50% will result in an increase in profits of 50%, assuming that the decreased cost also increases efficiency. Why is this statement FALSE?
column11: Profits will increase by more than 50 percent.

column14: Because they will know how many products have been sold.
column15: What is average cost?
column17: The average cost of resources per unit produced.

column20: It can help them determine the cost of expansion.
column21: What is total cost?
column23: The total cost of resources for a given good's production.

column9: XYZ Bicycles is trying to make production decisions for the future. Currently, XYZ is able to sell the next bicycle they will produce for more than it costs them to make. Should XYZ increase production, and why?
column11: Yes, they should increase production, because the sales would allow them to open more stores to overtake their competition.
column12: Which of these is a straight horizontal line on a total cost curve?
column14: Fixed Cost

column17: Because the costs of production are always highest at the beginning, and never rise at the same rate in the future.
column18: Which of these is a variable cost?
column21: Which of these is the total cost?
column23: Variable cost plus fixed cost

column9: When would a price go below 0?
column11: If the consumer pays the producer to stop.

column14: Too much of a good thing is bad.

column17: The hundredth unit consumed.
column18: At which point should a producer stop producing goods, according to the law of diminishing marginal returns?
column20: The last unit that the consumer pays for that is sold above the manufacture price.
column21: What is a util?
column23: An imaginary measure of utility.

column9: Company Z produces 10,000 units in a year. It has fixed costs of $50,000, direct labor costs of $50,000, and direct material costs of $100,000. What is the unit cost for Company Z's product?

column14: The total cost to produce a product divided by the number of units produced.

column18: Which of the following is a fixed cost?
column21: Which of the following is a variable cost?

column14: Fixed

column20: Fixed cost: car payment; variable cost: insurance.

column24: 3. Alpha Company Ltd is looking to lease a photocopier. The monthly lease for the photocopier is $65 and an additional charge of $0.05 per copy. Calculate the lease cost of the photocopier during the month of July if the expected number of copies is 50,000.

column38: As the number of products increases, the variable costs increase.

column9: 1. Sandra is a veterinarian who is planning to start a new practice in Columbus, Ohio. Which of these is a variable cost of starting her business?

column14: They can determine how much of which resources they need to acquire.

column17: No additional cost.

column9: 1. Describe what happens to the short-run production curve of a coffee shop that hires its second employee.
column11: Output rises dramatically

column14: Production that the firm can complete without capital upgrades to its factories

column17: Short-run production

column23: Output is near 0, because there are too many employees working at once, which hinders production.

column9: 1. Producers should focus on utility for all of the following reasons, EXCEPT:
column11: A lack of focus on utility could result in a lack of clarity about corporate goals.

column14: Paying craftspeople high wages to do detailed work on the guitar bodies.

column17: Having massive stockpiles of all resources necessary for production except for one, which is currently out of stock.

column20: It helps them to maximize profits.

column23: By pointing out that the helicopter would allow key employees with a very rare skill set to visit three plants in one day, instead of their current ability to visit one plant every three days by car.

column9: 1. Which of these scenarios are indifference curves used to measure?

column9: 1. How are indifference curves useful?

column9: 1. How are indifference curves useful?

column17: A helmet.
column18: 4. What do indifference curves measure?
column20: The impact of the demand of good X on the demand for good Y.

column23: Yes, all goods are interconnected because they are all sold in the same marketplace.

column9: 1. Points on the rate of transformation curve indicate which of the following?
column11: That one has spent all his/her money but not a penny more

column14: They indicate that a consumer cannot afford a purchase.

column17: The points inside the curve indicate that one does not have enough money for a purchase.

column23: The amount of two goods you can get for a specific amount of money

column9: 1. What can economists assume about consumers?
column11: Their decisions will maximize utility.
column12: 2. Which of the following is an example of a preference?
column14: Consumers preferring to save money rather than spend it on a good.

column17: The idea that consumers are always trying to not only maximize their utility but find new ways of doing so.

column23: Offer a 20% off coupon for all new customers making their first purchase at ABC.

column9: 1. What assumption focuses on consumer choices that result in different outcomes such as happiness, satisfaction, or utility?
column11: Consumer preference

column14: Transitivity

column17: Utility

column23: Completeness

column9: 1. What is the shape of the Engel curve of a normal good?
column11: Starting low, rising as it moves to the right, eventually stopping

column14: To determine how much of a given good consumers can afford based on their income.

column20: Because people only need so much of a given good.

column23: Starting high, rising as it moves to the left, eventually stopping

column23: It will shift to the left, slightly.

column9: How can utility change?

column9: Let's say that the supply of high quality agave syrup goes up by around 20%, while, thanks to an incredible and ingenious marketing campaign, the demand for this high quality agave syrup has raised the price 40%. What is the elasticity of supply and is this elastic or inelastic?

column12: How does price elasticity of demand and cross price elasticity of demand differ?

column9: Which of the following is NOT an inelastic demand for a product?

column12: Elasticity of demand is said to be elastic when elasticity is:
column14: Greater than 1.

column17: change in quantity demanded/change in price

column21: If a 10% change in price leads to a 30% change in the quantity demanded, then what is the elasticity?

column9: In economics, scarcity means that:

column9: In writing technical instructions, which one is not an example of the ethical issue of fairness?

column12: Why is it important to include safety warnings in a product's instructional manual?
column14: To comply with US Federal law requirements

column18: Which of the following is included first in MOST technical instructions?

column9: You hold a PhD in nuclear engineering and are seeking a new academic position in nuclear physics. When finalizing your vita for submission, which of the following of information should not be included?

column23: Keep it direct and short

column9: Dr. Resume warns that this type of resume distribution does not keep software specific formats. Which type of distribution is he referring to?

column23: HR staff hate certain fonts and throw out resumes written in them.

column9: What should an experienced worker do when writing a resume?

column12: What is a resume?
column14: A summary of qualifications, achievements, and education.
column15: If you are applying for different positions with varying qualifications, how many resumes should you write?
column17: Write one resume that can be quickly changed to put in the new job position for each application.
column18: Why would a job seeker include selling points in his or her resume?
column20: To highlight how you could be a valuable resource to the company.
column21: What is the first step a job seeker should take prior to applying for a position of interest?

column9: Which of the following would NOT likely be considered appropriate to include in the Personal Accomplishment section of a resume?

column15: All of the following are considered to be integral parts of a professional resume EXCEPT _____.

column21: Alan has just received a verbal offer of employment but wants to confirm the terms of employment. What type of letter may Alan write?
column23: An acceptance letter

column9: What is a major benefit of a well-written chronological resume for the employer?

column12: A resume that focuses on skills is known as what type of resume?

column15: Mrs. Smith is submitting a resume for an open English teacher position electronically. Since the resume is not being submitted through a website resume builder, what kind of resume should Mrs. Smith focus on writing?

column18: Which of the following is NOT TRUE about an online resume?

column21: What is the PROBABLE reason that an entry-level resume is more likely to spend significant time outlining volunteering experience?
column23: A person seeking an entry level position does not include any prior employment history other than unpaid, volunteer positions.

column9: Which one is the first step of writing a memo?
column11: Deciding if a memo is necessary

column21: Which one is not a part of a memo?
column23: Saying what people should do to help

column26: Include details of who is to blame for this change in procedure.

column9: Xander was asked by his boss to find out if there are any off-the-shelf alternatives available to replace the company's current database program. What would likely be the BEST type of memo for Xander to compose?
column11: A response memo.

column14: A status memo.

column23: A response memo.

column18: What is the first section of a memo?
column21: Which one would be an appropriate recipient of a memo from the president of an American company?

column9: Joe is checking his email during the workday. Which of the following is NOT an appropriate use of email?

column14: Professional

column17: The recipient of the email will be able to identify the purpose of the message quickly.
column18: Which of the following is an example of a valediction?
column21: Which of the following is a best practice for formatting an email?
column23: Using headings and subheadings with a simple and common font.

column9: Why should someone write a business letter when most of today's communications are typically informal between companies and clients?
column11: To ensure that everyone is on the same page when it comes to business decisions

column14: Thanking the client for their business

column17: Ensuring that the letter is truly necessary

column20: All of the answers are correct

column14: All of the answers are correct

column17: heading, recipient's address, salutation

column21: Which of the following is an appropriate closing phrase for a business letter?
column23: All of the answers are correct

column9: Jennifer lives an hour north of where she works and is stuck in traffic due to a water main break that her teammates, who mostly live within minutes of the office, probably know nothing about. Jennifer needs to let them know that she will be late to work and will be unable to run an early morning meeting for a client. Which of the following is the best form of communication for her to use?
column11: Text message

column14: They can serve as a replacement for memos.
column15: Becky works in a real estate office and wants to send a formal communication to thank a recent client for choosing her to market and sell his home. Which of the following form of communication should Becky utilize?
column17: Letter
column18: Mark is a manager who needs to communicate a new policy to his team members. Which of the following form of communication should Mark use for this purpose?
column21: Sally needs to ask her manager if she can leave a little early this afternoon in order to take her dog, who has just fallen ill, to the vet. Which of the following form of communication should she use?
column23: Email

column9: Text messaging is an example of which one of the following?
column11: Emailing

column14: An online service with compatible software that communicates instantaneously
column15: Which of the following is an example of NOT following the guideline to use correct grammar, punctuation, and word usage?
column17: RU coming 2 the meeting?

Use correct grammar and punctuation. III. Keep business and personal contacts separate. IV. Keep it short, sweet, and smart.
column21: What is the most important item that a company should have relative to the use of mobile message communication?

column11: Short and attention getting

column14: Writing Skill

column17: Short title in subject line

column21: Why should you never type an email in ALL CAPITAL LETTERS?
column23: The receiver will think you are shouting at him.

column9: Bob has been a loyal customer of Mary's Diner for several years. However, he recently mentioned to Mary that he's becoming annoyed by the volume of emails he receives describing the daily specials and new menu items being introduced. What can Mary do to help ensure she retains Bob as a customer? Choose the best answer.
column11: Assist Bob in opting out, or decreasing the number, of electronic communications
column12: Sending a monthly electronic message showcasing new car inventory would be an example of _____.
column14: an email campaign

column17: any communication sent by computer, phone or fax
column18: Which of the following is a disadvantage of electronic communication?
column21: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of electronic communication?
column23: Able to flood customers with email advertising every day

column9: A company has 15 different locations across the country in different states. It is experimenting with the use of a wiki so that engineers can collaborate on a new product design and share results from preliminary testing. What can the company do to ensure that all of the engineers are not overwriting important data posted by someone else?
column11: They can make someone in charge of maintaining the wiki and making corrections.
column12: What does asynchronous connection enable employees to do?
column14: Work without time constraints.
column15: In a business context, what is a wiki?
column17: A text oriented website that is hosted on an intranet within a company that allows all employees to add, remove, edit, upload and share content.
column18: A disadvantage of wikis is:
column20: Complex files may not be able to be uploaded.

column23: Allows companies to publish and share documents easily.

column9: Which section of the executive summary shows the important discoveries made during the research process?
column11: Findings or issues
column12: Why is it important for the executive summary to be able to stand alone from the original business report?
column14: Upper management reviews the summary to decide whether or not to read the entire report, so it needs to contain all pertinent information
column15: No more than one page
column17: No more than one page
column18: The subject matter, background problem, _____, methods of analysis, findings or issues, and the final section containing arguments, conclusions, & recommendations are six sections that make up the executive summary.
column21: The _____ section of the executive summary explains the reason for the report.
column23: Background problem

column9: What are repetitive patterns such as growth or decline data over time?
column11: Data trends
column12: How would the planning process for an analytical report differ from that of an informational report?
column14: Informational reports should include more information about the audience and trends in data analysis
column15: As part of your new position, you have been asked to prepare a monthly report on the number and types of mortgage loan applications that were received. What would be your first step as you begin to develop this informational report?
column17: Analyzing the situation

column20: Offer a set of specific detailed action plans
column21: What characteristic defines an informational report?
column23: It offers data, facts, and feedback without analysis or recommendations.

column9: Which report provides critical feedback and updates on projects?
column11: Status
column12: Which report uses informational reporting that contains facts about monitoring and controlling operations?
column14: Decision-making
column15: Which report examines the success of past or current decision making?
column17: Feasibility
column18: Which report provides advantages and disadvantages of taking a specific course of action such as whether to purchase a competitor?
column21: A human resource manager for a small company is revising the company's employee handbook. Which report type should the human resource manager generate for this project?
column23: Problem solving

column9: A researcher is writing a report on how well a new type of medicine can improve the blood pressure of patients taking it. He is short on time though, and uses data that he finds in a filing cabinet that another researcher compiled. What this researcher is doing can be best described as which of the following?
column11: Confidentiality violation
column12: A researcher's group of participants includes 5 male students and 1 female student. The researcher reports the data with the participants separated by gender. The researcher has violated the _____ of the female student by allowing her data to be singled out.
column14: confidentiality
column15: Permission gained after explaining all possible risks and benefits is called _____.
column17: informed consent
column18: Which of the following is NOT an honesty issue in formal report writing?
column21: A teacher is studying the effects of a new teaching strategy on the success of her Algebra students. Since she wants her school to formally adopt this new method of instruction, she changes a few numbers in her data set to make the strategy seem more successful than it really was. Has the teacher violated any rules in her reporting?
column23: Yes, the ethical thing to do is to present the information clearly and accurately, despite the teacher's desire for different results.

column9: Carl was asked to create a report about sales trends over the past ten years. What kind of research data would Carl need?
column11: Quantitative
column12: Two types of research data can appear in reports. Which grouping below includes both types of research data?
column14: Qualitative and quantitative
column15: Kisha is creating a sales report. In it, she wants people to be able to quickly see how steeply sales have declined month over month. What kind of visuals would be most helpful for Kisha to use?
column17: Charts
column18: Which of these is an example of qualitative research?
column20: Concerns voiced by members of the sales floor team
column21: Jim's company has recently opened branch offices in several countries where they had not been located in the past. What technique might best help those reading Jim's report on the company's growth to quickly grasp this progress?
column23: A map highlighting countries where the new branch offices are located.

column9: Carol is writing an evaluation report for City Council. Council members are already familiar with the background of the issue and the criterion by which things are being evaluated. They are most interested in knowing her recommendations. Knowing this, which organizational structure should Carol use in her report?
column11: Summary
column12: In his report, Carlos discussed how a product lived up to each criterion. If you wanted to read this, what section of Carlos' report should you turn to?
column14: Evaluation
column15: Kathy received an evaluation report written by one of her employees. She immediately turned to the section labeled 'Criteria.' What should Kathy expect to find in that section?
column17: Information about which requirements will be used to evaluate the product
column18: LaToya created a chart showing her department's performance for each evaluation criterion. In which section would LaToya include this chart in her report?
column21: James is writing a series of evaluation reports for the company's newly formed interdepartmental strategy team. Team members are from a variety of departments and are not universally familiar with the history of the issues or the criterion by which James is evaluating the data. Knowing this, which organizational structure should James use in her report?
column23: Traditional

column9: Why is the requirements section of a feasibility report often referred to the criteria section?
column11: Because it describes how the writer evaluates the feasibility of the proposed solution.
column12: Hector is writing a feasibility report and needs to include information about the history of the company and specific regulations that affect their work. Which section of the report should include this information?
column14: Background
column15: Under which set of conditions would you decide to follow a traditional organization within a feasibility report?
column17: When you need to prepare the report for a staff meeting with co-workers and are introducing the information for the first time.
column18: Under what circumstances would you need to write a feasibility report?
column20: When the possible solutions will all lead to unfavorable outcomes for the company and there needs to be documentation.
column21: Which organization follows the introduction with the conclusions and recommendation sections before explaining the background, requirements, and evaluation?
column23: Executive

column9: Theresa decides to use the _____ organization in her recommendation report since she knows that her manager wants to read the recommendation right away because he is in meetings most of the week. She also knows that he will go back and read the rest of the supporting detail contained in the report when he has more time and returns to the office next week.
column11: Executive summary
column12: The _____ organization of a recommendation report lists all seven sections in order to create a very long and detailed report.
column14: Executive summary
column15: A/An _____ is a paper that compares two or more solutions or products and makes a recommendation about which is the best option.
column17: Recommendation report
column18: Clarissa is writing a recommendation report for an event venue, and she needs to explain why she is not considering all of the possible venues in town. Clarissa should explain how she narrowed down the list in the _____ section of her report.
column21: The criteria in the category-by-category comparison section are described in the _____ section.
column23: Requirements

column9: Which of the following is the appropriate part of a formal report to mention a survey of local citizens who don't think their town is the appropriate place for building a new sports stadium?
column11: Text
column12: When you are preparing a formal report for someone who may be unfamiliar with the type of work that you are describing, it is important to include a _____ of terms the reader might not understand.
column14: Glossary
column15: Bob, the CEO of a company, receives a formal report from Sam, one of his executives. He is very busy though, and just wants the quick facts about the project covered in the report. What section should Bob read to meet his goals?
column17: Executive Summary
column18: What are the three main components of a formal report?
column21: A team of builders and architects are working together to design a new shopping mall in an existing building. It has been determined that there are some electrical problems in the building that will be used for the mall. The owner of the building is now considering scrapping the project because of the cost of repairing the problem. Is a formal report the appropriate way for the team to communicate their recommendations on the project to the owner of the building?
column23: Yes, because formal reports may be used to provide a recommended course of action.

column9: Analyze the report titles listed below and indicate which one is most likely a recommendation.
column11: Market Street or Main Street? The Best Choice for our New Location
column12: Tim's boss assigned him the task of determining if the company has the resources to open a second location. What kind of report will Tim write?
column14: Feasibility
column15: Ethan was assigned to write a report about new menu options for the restaurant. He included a few pages comparing customer preferences between booths and tables. What standard did Ethan violate in his report?
column17: Focused
column18: A formal report is most often distributed to:
column20: companies that will publish the information
column21: Kimberly needs to write a report that evaluates her program by set criteria to determine whether it is effective. What kind of report does Kimberly need to write?
column23: Evaluation

column9: The data Kevin found for his report says one thing, but his boss wants the report to say the opposite. Evaluate the choices below and select the most ethical choice Kevin can make in this situation.
column11: Include the evidence, even if the company won't like it.
column12: Ira has to write a report, and he realizes that he wrote a paragraph in an old report that would be great for the new one. If Ira takes the paragraph and adds it to the new report without mentioning his old paper, Ira is:
column14: guilty of plagiarizing his own work
column15: Cheryl is asked to provide an informal written report for her boss. Which format would be beyond the scope of her assignment?
column17: A thesis
column18: Cheryl is reviewing her report before presenting it to her boss. She is specifically checking the items listed below. Which of the items is not related to ethical issues of fairness?
column20: Including all relevant data and presenting it accurately
column21: Informal reports are:
column23: between two or more people in the same organization

column9: Which of the following is FALSE about incident reports?
column11: They always include a recommendation.
column12: Which of the following is typically found in an incident report?
column14: Description of an event that took place
column15: Where would you include a discussion of the purpose within the actual incident report?
column17: Recommendations
column18: What part of an incident report identifies any witnesses to the event and summarizes their respective testimony?
column21: A local grocery store stocks grapes in the produce section. A customer unknowingly knocks a grape off of the display. It is later smashed and mopped over by the janitorial staff. Because pieces of the grape dry on the floor, a small section becomes more slippery. Later in the day, another customer walks by the grape display and falls on that part of the floor. What would be the most appropriate style of discussion within the incident report?
column23: Chronological formatting, because a number of related events occurred within a period of time leading to the incident.

column9: Why is it important for a research report to allow others to replicate the results?
column11: To demonstrate the trustworthiness of the findings.
column12: Jim submitted a research report for publication. The publisher sent it back saying that Jim included too much unnecessary information in his report. The section headings of Jim's report are listed below. Indicate the section he could eliminate because the information in it is unnecessary for a research report.
column14: Procedure
column15: Why do research reports written with a specific format save other scientists time?
column17: Scientists can quickly find what they need.
column18: In her report, Rene wants to include the reason she chose her particular topic instead of other similar ones. In which section of the report should Rene include this information?
column21: Consider the accomplishments listed below. Which person would most likely need to include a research report?
column23: Someone who discovered a procedure that can help increase student test scores.

column9: Crystal is organizing the body of her progress report. Evaluate the options she listed below and choose the one that is best for her.
column11: Work Completed, Work in Progress, Work to be Started
column12: Mike's boss said he included unnecessary information in his progress report. Analyze Mike's section headings below and determine the one he could appropriately eliminate.
column14: Fees Associated with a Project
column15: A summary of the project and project goals are included in the _____ section of the progress report.
column17: Introduction
column18: A major client is bringing in a group of managers to see how well Jim's company is progressing on the project they hired Jim to do. What type of progress report will the client likely be expecting?
