column23: Conclusion

column9: LaToya noticed that her company was mentioned in three different letters to the editor in the local newspaper. She wrote up a report for her supervisor summarizing the content of these letters. What kind of report did LaToya write?
column11: informational
column12: Sheila is responsible for selecting a fleet of new vehicles for her company. She is unsure if a hybrid or regular car would serve best. She asks Jim to compare the two and give her a report with his recommendations. What kind of report is Sheila asking Jim to write?
column14: informational
column15: Informal reports are usually relatively _____.
column17: short
column18: Jared's boss wants him to write a short report telling him what the sales team has accomplished so far on this quarter's goals. What kind of report will Jared write?
column21: A brief memo or email within an organization is called a(n) _____ report.
column23: informal

column9: When should you revise the product?
column11: After testing
column12: Which of these demonstrates why it is important to understand the intended users of an app?
column14: A bunch of college students may not have the necessary knowledge to use a manual for a rocket.
column15: How should usability testing handle large products?
column17: Only test one or two aspects of the product.
column18: What is the first step of usability testing for an app or technical document?
column20: Defining the goals of the app or document
column21: Which of these does NOT require a usability test?
column23: All of these could benefit from a usability test.

column9: If you were writing a manual for a wide audience on how to assemble a bed, which of these should make up the majority of your test group?
column11: Random people
column12: Who should record the reactions of the test group during usability testing?
column14: The test group and those watching the test
column15: Which of these would likely require usability testing?
column17: A manual for a new productivity application
column18: How many rounds of usability testing are required?
column20: As many rounds that are economically viable and needed to get the final product right
column21: What criteria should you apply when selecting test participants for usability testing?
column23: It doesn't matter because everyone offers feedback based on their experience

column9: What is the goal of usability testing?
column11: To ensure the document is accurate and complete so people can use a product.
column12: If a tester finds something that needs to be changed, what should they do?
column14: Stop and incorporate the change into the final document.
column15: Which of the following would require usability testing?
column17: A furniture assembly manual.
column18: What is the purpose of technical writing?
column20: To quickly and efficiently transfer information or process knowledge.
column21: What should individuals do when performing usability testing?
column23: Follow the directions exactly as stated in the document.

column9: Which of these is an example of a formal written technical report?
column11: A typed update to a publisher on the status of a cookbook.
column12: Which of these is an example of an oral informal report?
column14: Leaving a voicemail on your teammate's cell phone.
column15: Sarah's boss asks her to prepare a formal report for their client. Which of the following options is most likely to align with her boss' expectations?
column17: A detailed presentation that includes charts and graphs.
column18: Which of the following is an informal written report?
column20: A quick note from a supervisor about a scheduling conflict.
column21: Daniel is phoning a potential employer after submitting his resume. Which of the following is Daniel doing?
column23: Making a formal oral report.

column9: Why does layout matter when writing a technical document?
column11: Documents that are difficult to read may be put aside and ignored.
column12: Which font would be the most appropriate choice for a technical document?
column14: Size 12 Times New Roman
column15: Which text should be highlighted (bolded, italicized, or underlined) within a technical document?
column17: Important pieces of information.
column18: Which of these is NOT acceptable in technical documents?
column21: You are writing a memo that will be shared with the rest of the organization. What type of layout should you AVOID using?
column23: One that incorporates the Times New Roman font.

column9: Corbin is reading a document report about something that is new to him. He comes across a word he doesn't know but seems essential to understand the meaning of the report. If the report is well written, it will include a/an _____ to help him make sense of the technical jargon.
column11: glossary
column12: What should be included in the body of the text to indicate a footnote?
column14: A superscript number
column15: Which scenario describes when a writer SHOULD NOT use a footnote in their writing?
column17: When the writer needs to provide a citation for a figure that was published somewhere else originally.
column18: Glossaries and appendices are contained in which part of the document?
column21: A writer wants to include additional information in her work for her readers. Which of the following belongs in the appendices to the document, and not in the main text or footnotes?
column23: Maps and photos

column9: Why should a company refrain from downplaying or ignoring negative data about a product?
column11: It can hinder sales and cause legal issues down the road
column12: Your company sells a weight loss shake, and 25% of your consumers have lost weight by drinking it. You then advertise that 75% of consumers lost weight by using the product in a bar chart in a commercial. Which of the following guidelines is the company not adhering to?
column14: Do not overestimate results
column15: An electronics store claimed, without any credible data, that sales of a particular 4DTV had increased after hiring a new group of sales representatives. Management displayed this information graphically on a bar chart and included it in a monthly report. Which of the following guidelines is not being followed?
column17: Do not imply cause and effect relationships
column18: Which of the following examples does not follow the guideline of providing accurate visuals?
column20: A photo of a diamond ring that implies the diamond is twice as large as it actually is
column21: What are ethical considerations?
column23: Morals and standards of right and wrong that are adhered to in a business communication

column9: Todd is collecting data via a survey to determine how satisfied his company's customers are with the service they receive after purchasing a product. Todd's survey utilizes a scale from 1 to 5 that represents 'very unsatisfied' up through 'very satisfied'. His survey is collecting _____ data.
column11: Ordinal
column12: Farah is using a bar chart to present the breakdown of customers who purchase her company's core product by hair color. This is an example of which of the following types of data?
column14: Nominal
column15: Alex needs to convey some precise financial information to his company's Board of Directors in a quarterly report. How should he present this information?
column17: Using text on a PowerPoint slide
column18: Visual graphics_____, while textual graphics _____.
column20: illustrate relationships and communicate a pattern through bar, pie, and line charts; create a message of detailed data mainly through the use of tables
column21: Which of the following types of charts is best used to show cumulative totals?
column23: Stacked Bar

column9: Pictures, charts, and tables which help to illustrate data to form a business message are known as _____.
column11: visuals
column12: Fun Town wanted their shareholders to increase their investments in ride safety. The marketing team decided to show photos of injuries that customers sustained from their competitors who enacted new rides, but did not spend the money on additional security measures. This is an example of visuals _____.
column14: reinforcing a written or verbal message
column15: Aubrey is putting together her small business's quarterly report and has decided to include some pie charts to help explain the recent sales data and future projections. This is an example of what visual role?
column17: Summarizing information
column18: The use of visuals in online slideshare programs is an example of how a well-prepared visual communication message can globally reach viewers to share information easily by _____.
column21: Fun Town added photos of laughing families and smiling children to its slideshow to demonstrate how much consumers love their product. What is the role of visual communication in this example?
column23: Reinforcing a written or verbal message

column9: When a recommendation is needed, what should the writer include in the first sentence?
column11: a clear statement of the basic problem for which the recommendation is being made
column12: When writing a recommendation in a technical paper, the conclusion statement should be sure to _____.
column14: create a connection between the data and the recommendation; lead into the recommendation
column15: Jaleel is an expert in the subject matter about which he is writing. Should he include a recommendation in his document?
column17: Even though he is an expert, Jaleel should only include a recommendation when the purpose of the document calls for one.
column18: In technical writing, what is a recommendation?
column20: suggested steps or actions to take as a result of the information provided in a document
column21: Jill is a civil engineer. She has been contracted by the city to design upgrades to an aging bridge in the center of town that will increase traffic flow in the area. During her evaluation of the bridge, she found some safety concerns due to its age and changes in the surrounding geography. Jill's report on the bridge will now include a recommendation to enhance safety. What should Jill include in her recommendation?
column23: a specific plan for what she thinks should be done to fix the problem

column9: What should the first sentence of the conclusion focus on in a technical document?
column11: A general finding that emerged from the data
column12: Why should personal pronouns be avoided in conclusions of a technical document?
column14: To prevent the reader from assuming the conclusion is based on opinion instead of research.
column15: Which data should be included first in a technical document?
column17: The data that most strongly supports your claim.
column18: What is the difference between a conclusion and a summary in a technical document?
column20: A summary analyzes data, while a conclusion restates what the document said.
column21: What should be included if you present contradicting data in a technical document?
column23: An explanation of how your original conclusion is still the most logical based on a combination of all the data.

column9: What type of language should be used in the introduction?
column11: Specific language to identify the specific topic being discussed
column12: Why is providing background information important?
column14: It provides context for the specific topic being discussed
column15: What is the purpose of an introduction?
column17: To provide a preview of the document's content, while explaining why the information is needed
column18: How are introductions and abstracts different?
column20: Introductions set the context, purpose and structure of the document while abstracts explain the results and conclusions of the research
column21: How should the purpose statement be written?
column23: By using a declarative sentence that states the desired outcome of the document

column9: John's team is tasked with creating the closed specifications of a complex new product that a company has developed. When John presents these specifications to the manufacturer, what is the manufacturer expecting to find in them?
column11: Every requirement that must be met during production or assembly plus all third party requirements
column12: What are technical specifications?
column14: Detailed explanations of the required design and materials that must be used to create a product
column15: What are the two different types of specifications?
column17: Required and optional
column18: Why are most technical specifications from the government considered open specifications?
column20: Government specifications provide performance and/or end product requirements without specifying how those requirements are to be achieved.
column21: Why should a writer use the word 'shall' when drafting technical specifications?
column23: To clearly identify items that are required

column9: You are writing a long description and have documented a definition of an item. What additional information should be included to adequately describe the item?
column11: An explanation of the function and a description of the item's physical features
column12: What are descriptions in technical writing?
column14: Explanations of the physical qualities of an item
column15: When writing short descriptions, what information should be included?
column17: The name, necessary background information and physical features of the item
column18: Descriptions are used in technical writing when _____
column20: instructing customers how to use the features of a product.
column21: If you are describing the physical characteristics of an item, what types of information should be included?
column23: The size, color, texture, and shape of an item

column9: What type of words should be used when writing technical definitions?
column11: words that the general public can understand
column12: You have been assigned the job of writing a manual for some new software. In the phrase, 'download program updates conveniently from our website,' you need to define the term 'download.' Which of these should you keep in mind as you are composing the definition?
column14: You should use another verb to classify the term download.
column15: When writing a definition in a technical paper, how should one provide the information for the distinguishing features of the term?
column17: use phrases that are clear and concise, remove anything that is not vital to understanding
column18: Which of the following is the best example of classifying a term using specific language?
column20: A Karst feature is a geomorphic feature formed from the dissolution of carbonate bedrock.
column21: Which of the phrases below best displays how a writer should use an example to expand the definition of a term in a technical document?
column23: _____ is very similar to the way water comes out of a faucet.

column9: Which of the following could be the result if you're caught falsifying data within a document?
column11: Negative consequences for your company's reputation.
column12: What should technical writers do to avoid plagiarism?
column14: Try to use only your own words and ideas or give credit to anything you get from another source.
column15: How can technical writers keep their documents unbiased?
column17: Only report the facts that support your opinion.Use language that is discriminatory in nature.
column18: What should you do to ensure that all of your data is factual?
column20: Check your facts prior to finalizing a report.
column21: Mary is writing ad copy for a new product being marketed by her company. She includes language that implies the consumer would be a fool not to purchase such a wonderful, innovative new product. This would be considered an example of:
column23: Connotation

column9: Which of the following does NOT require preparation of a quick reference sheet?
column11: A three-page memo.
column12: What is a disadvantage of defining terms in margins?
column14: It can make the margins cluttered.
column15: Which of the following is an example of a good use of a quick reference guide?
column17: A list of abbreviations.
column18: In technical writing, when is it most appropriate to use an appositive?
column20: To highlight familiar terminology in comparison to new information.
column21: You are writing a manual to introduce other employees to a new cloud-based software for your business. The software includes a number of terms that will be unfamiliar to most readers. What should you do to ensure the audience reads and learns the meaning of these terms?
column23: Prepare a glossary of terms that explains their meaning in detail.

column9: Why are extended definitions usually located in the introductory material of a document?
column11: The information is needed by readers to understand the subject matter of the document.
column12: Parenthetical definitions are _____, while sentence definitions are _____.
column14: a synonym or short phrase; an explanation of a word using one sentence
column15: What are the three parts of a sentence definition?
column17: The introduction, definition, and conclusion.
column18: What should an extended definition start with?
column21: Why are definitions included in technical writing?
column23: To improve reader comprehension.

column9: Which of the following is NOT an appropriate place to include a definition of a technical term?
column11: In the body of the document
column12: Which of the following is NOT important when determining the location of the definition?
column14: The reading level of the document
column15: When should a definition be used in technical writing?
column17: To explain the meaning of a word as it relates to the subject being discussed.
column18: Which of the following is NOT a good reason to choose a parenthetical definition over a sentence definition?
column21: While reading a piece of technical writing, you come across a sentence that defines a term. How can you tell whether this is a sentence definition or part of an extended definition?
column23: If the next few sentences continue to expand on the word's meaning, then it's part an extended definition.

column9: Why would executive summaries often contain specific financial data?
column11: They are written for business executives and managers.
column12: What are the three main types of summaries and abstracts?
column14: Descriptive abstracts, informative abstracts, and executive summaries
column15: Analyze the statements below and indicate which one provides the best guidelines for the recommended length for summaries and abstracts.
column17: Descriptive abstracts should be 1-2 sentences long while informative abstracts and executive summaries should be approximately 10% of the length of the document.
column18: The informative abstract that Sarah wrote is too long. She included the information listed below. Which information could Sarah remove from her abstract without negatively impacting it?
column21: What is the purpose of a summary and an abstract?
column23: To help readers to decide whether or not they need to read the complete document.

column9: Why is it sometimes necessary to include front matter?
column11: Front matter provides the reader an understanding of who should read the document, what it will be about, and how it will be organized.
column12: If additional maps or diagrams are needed to further explain content in the body of the document, which of the below should be included in the end matter?
column14: Table of contents
column15: What should be used to determine how much front and end matter to include in a document?
column17: The length and content of the document
column18: The information in the body of the document should be centered on what?
column21: What information should be included in the executive summary?
column23: The cost and time associated with the subject

column9: Why are second level headings sometimes referred to as 'talking headers'?
column11: They 'speak' to the reader in more specific language about an upcoming topic
column12: Which of the following is NOT true of first level headings?
column14: First level headings are incredibly specific, so that readers can skip to the portion of the document they want to focus on.
column15: What type of language should be used to write titles?
column17: Short, easy-to-understand phrases
column18: Mrs. Jones is producing a document for her peers about the value of using paper books in comparison to e-readers in the college classroom. The title of her document is 'E-Readers vs. Paper Books: An Analysis.' What is LIKELY one of most appropriate second level headings for her document?
column20: Student Interaction with Text via E-Readers
column21: A student has just completed a major research paper for one of his courses. The document is over 20 pages long. Where should he place his title?
column23: On a separate title page, with the title at the top of the page.

column9: What is a self-assessment?
column11: An analysis an individual performs on their own work
column12: Bubba listened to Sunny explain that the customers who had issues with her table requests were there during the busiest time periods. Because of this, she was unable to service all of her tables' requests in time. This is an example of which constructive feedback guideline?
column14: Let the recipient of the feedback respond.
column15: How should feedback be delivered?
column17: It should be delivered in a private meeting.
column18: What is the goal of providing constructive feedback in the workplace?
column20: Provide information about performance to promote improvement at work.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a suggestion for giving constructive feedback?
column23: Choose an appropriate setting to deliver feedback.

column9: Michael Jones, living in New York City USA, is collaborating with Linda Yeo, living in Beijing China, to write a research document resulting from data they have collected by sending the same letter to many research subjects. Which one would they have used to be effective in this activity?
column11: Mail Merge and File merge
column12: What is the name given to font and layout setting templates that are used to standardize documents in word processing software?
column14: Autocorrection
column15: What tool places a ready-made block of text automatically into a document?
column17: Autocompletion
column18: What is another name for a template?
column21: What name is given to tutorials that help create documents such as resumes, letters, etc automatically?
column23: Wizards

column9: 'Beautiful Scenery would like to hear any feedback or changes in the proposal by March 14th, 2016' is an example of:
column11: Mentioning response requirements.
column12: If Bobby wanted to elicit a response by appealing to readers' priorities, which of the following should he NOT include in his email?
column14: Any feedback we receive by March 15th, 2016 will be taken into account when deciding whether or not to increase the price.
column15: Which of the following is NOT appropriate advice for message follow-up?
column17: After one month, send an irate message.
column18: Which of the following is the best description of a message follow-up?
column20: It is an act of contacting an individual again through email, fax, text, etc. in the hopes of bringing about a positive response.
column21: According to business etiquette, how long should an individual wait before sending a follow-up message?
column23: Seven days

column9: How can a writer create unity among different paragraphs in a document?
column11: By using the same organizing pattern for the sentences in paragraphs.
column12: If you were asked to review a document for a colleague, how would you evaluate it for unity?
column14: You would check to make sure that each paragraph focuses on one topic, all paragraphs focus on one thesis, and whether the writing follows a similar paragraph structure.
column15: What does the concept of unity in a document do for the reader?
column17: Unity ensures the reader understands what motivated document creation.
column18: How should a technical report begin in order to provide focus and unity to the entire document?
column20: With a thesis statement to explain the purpose of the writing.
column21: What is the purpose of writing a topic sentence within every paragraph of a report?
column23: A topic sentence explains the general idea or message of a paragraph.

column9: When should the Table of Contents be included in a document?
column11: When the document is longer than ten pages.
column12: You are writing about the history of immigration into the United States during the 20th century. The main content includes the changing immigration policies during different administrations and the impact on the total population. What would be the most appropriate heading for the end of immigration following World War I in the 1920s?
column14: This paragraph details the changing immigration policy following World War I
column15: What type(s) of information should be included as part of a List of Figures?
column17: The name of the figure and the page number where it is located within the document.
column18: Why should writers use headings in technical documents?
column20: To provide a visual cue for important topics and break the information into smaller chunks.
column21: What is the purpose of a typographical cue?
column23: To emphasize a point.

column9: How long should most paragraphs be?
column11: Five to six sentences
column12: Why should you include a conclusion in your technical document?
column14: To reinforce the points you made in your document.
column15: On what aspect should your choice of organizational patterns be based?
column17: Your audience's needs and your document's purpose
column18: A university president sent out a very detailed email message to faculty, staff and students discussing how to resolve the feral cat problem on campus. The message included a lengthy survey to assess opinions on wildlife, feral cats and problem-resolution. The response rate was very low since most on campus were not aware of such a large problem. What should have the president done to achieve better results from his message?
column20: The message should have included a number of conclusions about why there were feral cats and who was feeding them.
column21: What information should be included in the introduction to a technical document?
column23: What the document is, an overview of the main points, why it is being sent, and what action needs to be taken.

column9: Which of the following would be an example of an unclear reference?
column11: Review your textbook along with the related worksheet labeled anatomy of a cat and circle the location of its stomach.
column12: What important step can writers take to verify their written documents follow basic grammatical rules?
column14: Proofread the final draft of the document
column15: What are some potential problems with written documents that are not easily understood?
column17: the document could lead to frustration and work-related errors
column18: When writing a technical document, the sentence length should be evaluated against what standard?
column20: Avoid the use of too many commas whenever possible
column21: What is one method of using words wisely to retain a reader's interest in a technical report?
column23: Including some variety in the way that sentences begin

column9: Why should you include visual cues in the text?
column11: To break text into easy to understand chunks and help readers quickly find information.
column12: Jeremy is writing the employee handbook for his organization. What visual cues could he incorporate to make the document visually complete?
column14: Create short headings that indicate the topic for each related group of paragraphs.
column15: How can you BEST ensure your document is usable?
column17: Make sure the information is easy to understand, engaging and valuable.
column18: Visual aids should be incorporated into a technical document:
column20: When it is a requirement by the employer or client.
column21: Which of the following is NOT an element of textual completeness?
column23: Follow guidelines for length

column9: Which term is used to refer to a situation when the score is based on 100 points with a higher score reflecting an easier read of the document?
column11: Flesch Reading Ease Score
column12: The ball balloon magnetic block game is expected to exceed sales is an example of:
column14: Long noun grouping
column15: Which one would you be achieving when you avoid dangling modifiers?
column17: Grammatical Challenge
column18: Which one is the most appropriate way to reduce writing errors in your documents?
column20: Utilize Spelling & Review option in Word.
column21: Which one ranks written documents by grade level achievement to help determine readability?
column23: Flesch-Kincaid Grade Level Index

column9: Which words can be eliminated to improve conciseness?
column11: Words that don't add to or express the main point of the message.
column12: What does it mean to be concise in writing?
column14: Use only the necessary amount of words to describe an idea.
column15: How can conciseness be achieved in technical writing?
column17: By eliminating unnecessary words, phrases, and verbs.
column18: Why should clichés be avoided in technical writing?
column20: They can be interpreted differently by different people, which leads to confusion.
column21: What type of verbs should technical writers use?
column23: State of being verbs

column9: Searching for spelling & grammar errors, checking for accuracy, and _____ are the steps involved in proofreading a message.
column11: All of the answers are correct.
column12: Which of the following is a known way to assist a writer with creating a clear and organized message?
column14: All of the answers are correct
column15: _____ is the process of examining a document to search for writing mistakes and omissions.
column17: Proofreading
column18: Which of the following describes the accuracy of a message?
column20: The degree the information represented is correct
column21: Janet has just completed writing a press release for her company. Janet wants to ensure that she does not have any spelling or grammar errors in her work, so she asks her co-worker, Meghan, to review the press release for her. This is known as _____.
column23: Peer review

column9: How can a writer ensure that a document is contextually correct?
column11: Verify the sources and proofread the document
column12: Which of the following sentences is NOT punctuated correctly?
column14: Dinner, which I typically eat at 6 PM, usually consists of something quick and easy.
column15: Why is using spell check not enough to ensure that the spelling in the document is correct?
column17: Spell check does not always pick up on incorrect word choice if the spelling of the word that is used is correct
column18: What can a writer do to ensure the style of the document is correct?
column20: Write in active voice, use an appropriate tone, and cut out unnecessary words
column21: Why is it important to ensure that the document you create is grammatically and contextually correct?
column23: Errors frustrate customers and make the business seem unprofessional

column9: Why should writers use an organizational pattern for their technical documents?
column11: To keep the writing clear and focused.
column12: Apple has recently released the newest version of their iPhone with some exciting new camera enhancements. The company wants to be sure that current iPhone users understand what makes the new smartphone so much better than the previous version. How should they organize their writing to promote the updates to readers?
column14: Utilize the compare and contrast style of writing.
column15: What should writers consider when choosing which organizational pattern to use in their writing?
column17: The location where the document will be displayed.
column18: Why might a writer choose to use the order of importance organizational pattern?
column20: To help readers understand that a certain issue needs to be addressed before other issues.
column21: Under which of the following situations would a writer consider using the spatial organizational pattern?
column23: When documenting the location of activities on a cruise ship.

column9: Why should acronyms not be used in technical writing until the original words are spelled out?
column11: Acronyms do not explain what the author wants the reader to do.
column12: How can writers ensure they include specific details in their documents?
column14: By addressing the 5 W questions and having someone review the piece for missed information.
column15: What is a possible problem when using cliches in technical writing?
column17: Not everyone is familiar with the expressions and can lead to misunderstanding of the information.
column18: Why is clarity important in technical writing?
column20: It will help prevent confusion among readers which will reduce frustration.
column21: Which of the following sentences is an example of writing using active voice?
column23: The board of directors approved a bonus of 25% for all employees.

column9: What is parallel structure?
column11: The use of the same grammatical form when presenting ideas.
column12: Which sentence has parallel structure?
column14: The writer must make strong points, stick to the subject, and use concise language.
column15: Why should parallel structure be used in technical writing?
column17: It allows the writer to emphasize repeated ideas in a piece of writing.
column18: Which sentence has parallel structure?
column20: He went to the store to buy an apple, a pear, a steak, a pineapple, a pie, and a pizza.
column21: Please choose the best option to complete the sentence below using parallel structure. In order to turn on your cell phone, you must
column23: hold down the ON button, wait five seconds, and swipe your finger across the screen.

column9: Check the parallelism of the following sentence. Choose the answer that best corrects the problem. Although he enjoyed running and to play baseball, he decided to try out for volleyball instead.
column11: Change to play baseball to playing baseball
column12: Check the parallelism of the following sentence. Choose the answer that best corrects the problem. He sat down at the table expecting to order, eat, and be enjoying his meal alone.
column14: Change be enjoying to enjoy
column15: When using coordinating conjunctions like but, and, or and so, writers should _____.
column17: edit to make the words on either side of the conjunction parallel
column18: Choose the most correct statement regarding parallel structure in a series of items.
column20: Parallel structure in a series often highlights verb tenses that agree.
column21: Check the parallelism of the following sentence. Choose the answer that best corrects the problem. We neither had money nor enough time to escape.
column23: We had neither enough money nor enough time to escape.

column9: What have you achieved when utilizing similar margins, typeface, typestyle, and colors throughout a document?
column11: Consistency
column12: What is the best margin format for business papers?
column14: Flush-Right
column15: You are working with a co-worker to complete a report on monthly sales in your department. He has included a large number of charts and graphs in each page with text wrapping around the right side. How would you assist him to create some restraint in the report?
column17: Limit the charts and graphs to the minimum needed to communicate your message and remove wrapping text.
column18: Which of the following typefaces would be the best choice for a business report to your manager?
column21: What technique is utilized to distribute the text and graphic elements evenly for an eye pleasing look?
column23: Balance

column9: What way of organizing a message is about examining why something happened or the effects of something occurring at work?
column11: Cause/Effect
column12: Santino has been asked to write a message detailing the route followed by a delivery truck to local Whole Foods stores throughout the day, noting the amount of time completing the delivery at each store. Which type of message structure should he use to outline his message?
column14: Chronological order
column15: A company memo or lab report is an example of:
column17: General Organizational Pattern
column18: What is a method where a writer explains a business problem and develops a solution?
column21: What organizational method involves organizing ideas in the order of most importance to least importance?
column23: Emphatic

column9: Which of the following is used to offer more evidence for the topic sentence?
column11: Supporting sentences
column12: Words or phrases that are used to help link a paragraph together and provide flow are known as _____.
column14: supporting words
column15: Where does a topic sentence usually appear in a paragraph within a business communication?
column17: It is usually the very first sentence in the paragraph.
column18: What are the three key pieces of developing a strong paragraph?
column20: Topic sentence, supporting sentences and transitions
column21: Which of the following words or phrases could be used as a transition?
column23: However

column9: Rachel went to the bank, but it was closed for the Christmas holiday. Why is this structure considered a compound sentence?
column11: It is made up of two independent clauses.
column12: What are the four types of effective sentence structures for business communication?
column14: Simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex
column15: While she waited at the drive-up lane, Rachel realized the bank was closed. What type of sentence structure is this?
column17: Complex sentence
column18: Rachel went to the bank. This is an example of a _____.
column21: Why is the following structure a compound-complex sentence? Rachel went to cash her check to have some extra money for the after-Christmas sales, but the bank was closed due to the holiday.
column23: It has one main clause containing a simple subject and a predicate.

column9: Passive verbs are usually recognized by _____
column11: the use of action verbs.
column12: 'At the Christmas concert, a woman from our church sang the soprano solo in 'O Holy Night'' is an example of which of the following?
column14: A sentence written in active voice
column15: Using active verbs strengthens the delivery of business writing by _____
column17: communicating something a person, animal or object can do.
column18: Why should an individual try to avoid the use of passive verbs in business writing?
column20: Passive voice is wordier and can lead to reader confusion.
column21: 'At the Christmas concert, the soprano solo in 'O Holy Night' was sung by a woman from our church' is an example of which of the following?
column23: A sentence written in passive voice

column9: What would be an example of nondiscriminatory language to use when describing a blind worker?
column11: A person who has a vision disability
column12: What would be a gender neutral word choice for fireman?
column14: Firewoman
column15: Which of the following would be considered an example of discriminatory language?
column17: Old man, I wasn't even alive yet when you started working at this company.
column18: Which of the following is an area that can present nondiscriminatory language challenges in the workplace?
column20: All of these answers are correct.
column21: Assume that you were writing a job description for a position with your company. How would you include information that reflects a nondiscriminatory mention of age in describing desired applicants?
column23: We are interested in anyone with bakery experience who is at least eighteen years of age or older.

column9: Directions provided to students in a communications class asked them to avoid 'extemporaneous preparations when planning required speeches'. The professor could avoid confusion by rewriting his directions incorporating which of the following strategies:
column11: Choosing recognizable words
column12: Steve has been asked to provide his staff an update on planned training activities for the next six months. In the past, he has received requests for clarification because his messages were excessively detailed and included glowing adjectives describing how great the sessions would be for employees. What should he do when writing the next message to provide more clarity and eliminate unnecessary questions?
column14: Choose robust/specific words including strong nouns and verbs.
column15: What is CADD or Computer Aided Drafting and Design an example of?
column17: Robust statement
column18: Executive Director Tim enjoys sending out lengthy emails to his staff summarizing articles he reads on educational topics. column23: You stole someone else's work and portrayed the work as your own when writing the paper.

column21: What is one potential problem of solely using focus groups as your primary research method?

column9: Which of these answers describes the term delegation?

column14: All of the answers are correct.

column9: Which of the following does not make legitimate power effective?

column23: Communication increases throughout the company.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Jill is concerned that her employees are stagnating and not developing their skills as she had hoped. Jill believes that _____ will help the employees assess their work and generate skill development plans.
column11: M.B.O.
column12: How would a manager implement Management by Objective (MBO) in her employee appraisals?
column14: By collaborating with each employee on goal setting
column15: The CEO of XYZ Corp. will be conducting reviews with his top managers. He has asked them to get feedback from lower level supervisors and outside vendors with whom they work. Which method is the CEO using to review his top managers?
column17: 360 Degree Feedback.
column18: Top-down appraisals measure employee performance against goals _____
column21: Employee appraisals are for _____.
column23: all employees

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Matt the manager is completing an appraisal that consists of answering multiple choice questions regarding his employees' traits. Which appraisal method is Matt using?
column11: Narrative
column12: A large corporation uses an appraisal method where the bottom 10% of employees must show immediate improvement or be terminated. Which appraisal method are they using?
column14: Forced distribution
column15: Edward is a supervisor evaluating an employee by writing an essay about the employee's performance. Which type of appraisal method is he using?
column17: Narrative
column18: Lisa is reviewing the results of recent performance appraisals that have been plotted on a graph in the form of a bell curve. Which type of performance appraisal can be graphically represented this way?
column21: Sarah the supervisor would like an appraisal system that doesn't rank employees or compare them with one another. Which appraisal method should Sarah use?
column23: Narrative

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of these is a major benefit to using graphic rating scales?
column11: They are based on work sampling.
column12: Sal is a supervisor for a cellphone assembly contractor. To design a new appraisal method, he has brought in a consultant. They will do a thorough job analysis to identify the most efficient way to assemble phones and the behaviors assemblers need to have. Which appraisal method are they working on?
column14: BARS
column15: Sara is a supervisor at a call center. She monitors her employees' calls and keeps a record for each employee of times when they provided exceptional customer service as well as when service was not helpful or substandard. Which appraisal method is Sara using?
column17: Critical incident
column18: Beth is a teller supervisor at the bank. She gives each teller a rating for their accuracy, customer service and salesmanship. Which appraisal method is Beth using?
column21: Which of the following appraisal methods uses vertical scales based, in part, upon job analysis?
column23: Graphic rating scales

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: What is a formal system used to assess performance and effectiveness of employees and teams of employees known as?
column11: None of the answers are correct.
column12: Justin is a university professor in economics. The criteria for his performance appraisal is his knowledge of economics and his ability to teach it to students. Which type of standards are being used in his appraisal?
column14: Competencies
column15: Fred is a football coach. The criteria for his appraisal will be how many games his team wins this year. Which type of standards are being used in his appraisal?
column17: Results
column18: Bethany is a salesperson at the cellphone store. Her performance appraisal is based on her ability to talk to the customers and build relationships with them. Which type of standards are being used in her appraisal?
column21: Kate is a data entry clerk. Part of her performance appraisal is how much she is never satisfied with her work if isn't perfect. Which type of standards are being used in her appraisal?
column23: Competencies

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: A performance appraisal using criteria correlated to the goal assessed has which characteristic?
column11: Relevancy
column12: An appraisal that can differentiate between effective employees and ineffective employees has which characteristic?
column14: Relevancy
column15: Sarah has complained that the performance appraisal her company has her use is too complicated for many to understand, and simply isn't very useable. Sarah is complaining that the performance appraisal is lacking:
column17: practicality.
column18: Bob did a performance appraisal for an employee in his department. Ellen works in the same department and did a performance appraisal for the same employee. Bob and Ellen got different results. What is the performance appraisal lacking?
column21: A performance appraisal supported by an organization's members has which characteristic?
column23: Acceptability

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Why would performance appraisals be useful to a company that is investing in employee development?
column11: To assess the effectiveness of their development training by evaluating the employee before and after
column12: Which of the following is NOT a developmental function of performance appraisals?
column14: Help determine individual training needs
column15: A performance appraisal is best used for:
column17: Evaluating an employee's past performance and helping future development
column18: Which of the following is NOT an administrative use of performance appraisals?
column21: What is a formal system of assessing an employee's effectiveness and productivity called?
column23: Performance appraisal

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of the following errors involves rating everyone pretty much as average?
column11: Central tendency error
column12: The executive director wants to save time on his performance appraisals of mid-level management. He rates all of his managers as excellent to finish the process quickly. Which rating error is being committed?
column14: Similar-to-me error
column15: A supervisor rated five very poor performers and then incorrectly rates the sixth as an above average performer even though the employee is only average. What type of rating error is this?
column17: Contrast error
column18: Steve is considering Paul's performance on the job within the last few months. Which of the following rater errors is he most likely to make because he is thinking about a current impression of an employee's performance?
column21: Which one of the following is a benefit of performance appraisals?
column23: Guide for offering promotions and raises

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Beth the bank manager wants to implement the hot stove rule in her discipline for employees breaking the rules. Which of these should she do?
column11: Discipline all employees who break rules consistently
column12: Joe has previously received verbal and then written warnings about taking long lunch hours, yet he continues to return one half hour later than he should. What should be the next step in progressive discipline for Joe?
column14: Just accept that Joe will not change his ways
column15: An automotive assembly line has strict rules about wearing safety glasses in work areas. Felix is a good employee with no prior rule violations. Today his supervisor sees him in the work area without his glasses. What should the manager do next under progressive discipline?
column17: Give Felix a verbal warning
column18: Matt the manager follows the hot stove rule of discipline. He observes one of his employees breaking a rule by making many personal phone calls on company time. What should Matt do next?
column21: What should the primary purpose be for engaging in an employee disciplinary action?
column23: To punish past behavior

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: How is Daniel Goleman relevant to the study of emotional intelligence?
column11: He helped bring the concept of emotional intelligence into the mainstream.
column12: Eddie is an innovative industrial engineer. Impressed by his intelligent approach to problem solving skills Eddie's boss is considering to promote him to shift supervisor. However, even though Eddie is good at his job his boss worries that Eddie may lack the emotional intelligence to manager other employees, i.e. being intuitive as to what other coworkers may feel and need. Based on Eddie's boss' evaluation, what domain of emotional intelligence may Eddie lack which could prove problematic in managing others?
column14: Managing relationships.
column15: Alyssa is a student in the second grade. Her teacher has noticed that while other students in class respond well to external rewards like stickers, extra recess time, or praise from the teacher, Alyssa is intrinsically motivated. Doing well is her reward. Alyssa demonstrates strength in which domain of emotional intelligence?
column17: Self-motivation
column18: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of emotional intelligence?
column20: It is the ability to understand and manage emotions for one's self and others.
column21: Diane has noticed that when someone puts her off, it ruins her whole day. She just can't shake it off, which really puts a damper on her production at work. She worries her boss will get mad, yet she just can't seem to focus on anything else. Diane is emotionally stuck. Which domain of emotional intelligence is troublesome for Diane?
column23: Managing emotions

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: What type of contract has an implicit agreement between an individual and an organization that details exactly what is expected in the relationship?
column11: Psychological
column12: Joan has been a store manager for six years. She loves her job and is not interested in a job as regional manager because she would have to move to another city. Which stage of the career model is Joan in?
column14: Productivity
column15: Don is a 50-year-old repair technician for a computer hardware company. He notices that all of the recent promotions have gone to younger techs with more recent college degrees. What point in his career has Don MOST likely reached?
column17: Career Plateau
column18: Susie plans to cut back her work hours and begin passing her responsibilities on to younger associates in anticipation of retirement. Which stage of the career model is Susie in?
column21: What are the four career stages?
column23: Establishment, advancement, maintenance and withdrawal

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of the following is an employee benefit associated with career development and management programs?
column11: The programs can find a job for employees who were unfortunately part of a company- wide layoff.
column12: What group would benefit from a career management development system focused on task forces?
column14: Managers
column15: Jackie has a sense of loyalty to her company now that it is paying for her graduate tuition. This is an example of _____.
column17: an organizational benefit of career development and management programs.
column18: What is the purpose of a career management and development systems?
column20: To offer programs, counseling, planning and workshops to help employees manage their careers.
column21: Which of the following is not a benefit of career development and management systems for managers?
column23: It increases salaries and benefits.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Cindi is the newly appointed head of the accounting department. She is receiving training from a mentor and meets with her trainer every day to discuss how the day went and any unusual problems she is facing. Which of the following is NOT an advantage of using this training method?
column11: It hones in on employee interests
column12: Using hands-on training while working alongside an experienced worker is called _____.
column14: hands-on experience
column15: Why can job rotation be harmful to the productivity of a company?
column17: Because it can disrupt the workflow as the employee learns a new task or job
column18: Juan is a newly hired assembler at Speedy Cellular. He will spend his first week with Juanita, a veteran assembler, who will work side by side with Juan, showing him each step of the assembly process as he assembles the phones. Why is this an example of on-the-job training?
column20: Because Juan is learning his job by performing a specific task or job
column21: In which of the following cases would a company MOST benefit from a job rotation program?
column23: When productivity and company revenue are increasing

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of the following provides the best explanation of employee assimilation?
column11: An employee becoming integrated into the company
column12: The following are advantages of a solid new hire orientation process EXCEPT _____.
column14: it completes the assimilation and socialization process
column15: Orientation for new employees includes the following components EXCEPT _____ to help with socialization and assimilation.
column17: providing an overview of the company's expectations regarding employee failure and resignation statistics
column18: A solid orientation program is important because _____.
column20: the chance of employee success is increased
column21: What's the best explanation of new hire orientation?
column23: Introducing a new employee to the organization and begin the socialization and assimilation process

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which type of training would MOST likely result in employees becoming more willing to work together and trust their coworkers?
column11: Diversity Training
column12: What are some of the possible benefits to training an employee in the use of new technology?
column14: Self-confidence and skills levels are improved
column15: Kathleen has a difficult time submitting project objectives and results to her supervisor in a clear and concise format. Her supervisor feels her reports are confusing. In order to improve Kathleen's skills in writing reports, her supervisor might recommend _____ training.
column17: Literacy
column18: Problem-solving training will teach employees to do all of the following, EXCEPT:
column21: Diversity training focuses on the recognition of cultural differences and improves the ability of employees to _____.
column23: work effectively with people who are different

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of these is a step in the process of assessing training needs?
column11: Take an inventory of what is presently being done
column12: Which of these would be a quick action that would aid in keeping current clients?
column14: Install the latest technology even if employees don't know how to use it
column15: What is the purpose for training needs assessments?
column17: They bridge the gap between what is happening now and what needs to happen in the future
column18: Which of the following should be reviewed when assessing training needs?
column21: A manager finds her employees are unfamiliar with the mission and vision of the organization. What type of training will solve the problem?
column23: Organizational culture training

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Carmen is a stay-at-home wife and wants to treat her parents to an expensive vacation for their 25th wedding anniversary. She gets a part-time job at a retail store and intends to quit once she earns enough money for her parents' trip. Carmen is an example of _____.
column11: a pre-planned quitter
column12: Diego works at a hardware store and has applied to an apprenticeship program with a local plumbers' union. He plans to quit his job if he is accepted into the apprentice program. Diego is a conditional quitter because:
column14: He is comparing his possibilities between the apprenticeship and his hardware store job
column15: Alicia's customer at the bridal shop was so difficult and rude that Alicia decided to quit on the spot. Why would this be considered impulsive quitting?
column17: Alicia made her decision in a quick and emotional moment
column18: Exit interviews are important to organizations because:
column20: They provide data on why employees leave and ways to retain them
column21: Ben sells cars and learns of another dealership with better commissions. He contacts the dealership and is offered a sales position. He accepts their offer and quits his current job. What type of quitter is Ben?
column23: Comparison

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Janice was just terminated. She was told her skills were not up to par for the company's needs. What type of termination did she undergo?
column11: Discharge
column12: Joe and a bunch of his buddies have just been terminated from employment because the company was able to reduce its labor requirements with new equipment. Why is this an example of a reduction-in-force?
column14: Upper management is trying to reduce costs due to a temporary business slowdown.
column15: Thomas quit his job to work for another company, while Jane retired after working 40 years. How does Thomas' termination compare to Jane's termination?'
column17: Both of these are examples of voluntary termination.
column18: Tom was terminated due to a slowdown in demand for his company's products. His employer tells him he will be called back when product demand increases. Why is this scenario an example of a layoff?
column20: Because the employer expects it to be temporary
column21: Which of the following factors increases the probability that an employee will quit?
column23: An employee has a specific skill set and the company has no competition.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Identify the first step that is involved in terminating an employee.
column11: Documenting employee performance and behaviors
column12: Why is it important to include a compelling reason for terminating an employee?
column14: It makes the boss feel better about firing someone.
column15: What changes should you recommend be incorporated in a written statement of termination?
column17: Adding the termination dates
column18: Thomas works in a PR company. The company's manager is not satisfied with his performance and wants to fire him. Why would it be a good idea to try to find an alternative to firing him, such as finding him a new post in the company?
column21: Which of the following is an example of a good question for an exit interview?
column23: Can you summarize in a few sentences whether or not you feel included in the company?

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: To motivate employees to stay with the company, the HR manager recommends an across the board pay raise, which will get the company wages up to current market level. What type of tool is this?
column11: Extrinsic motivation
column12: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of 'absenteeism'?
column14: The pattern or habit of employees missing work, often for no good reason
column15: Beth is feeling burnt out at work. She needs a change, so she decides to quit her job and take classes to become a real estate agent, which she thinks will provide her with a more flexible schedule. Which of the following describes this example?
column17: Extrinsic Motivation
column18: Which of the following may affect intrinsic motivation?
column21: Which of the following is the BEST explanation of 'turnover'?
column23: Replacing employees who left employment, either voluntarily or involuntarily

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Bob is looking to hire someone from within the company for a vacant position. He comes up with this as a job posting: ZZT Engineering is looking to hire someone from within the company to fill the position of Senior Engineer. The Senior Engineer will oversee all the Junior Engineers and their projects. You can apply on the company website, on the opportunities page. What is missing from this job posting?
column11: Job qualifications
column12: Rita is an HR specialist that wants to notify company employees of a vacancy. What is the name of the notification process?
column14: Job posting
column15: What do you call the process of attracting and selecting the most qualified candidates for positions in an organization?
column17: Applicant selection
column18: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of external recruitment?
column21: What do you call the process of employees applying for vacancies in their current organization?
column23: Job bidding

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: How do group interviews and panel interviews differ?
column11: A group interview involves at least two interviewers while a panel interview involves at least two applicants.
column12: Nina is interviewing for a position as manager of a new store location. The interviewer asks if she could talk about her past experience with new store situations. Nina is getting what type of interview?
column14: Behavioral
column15: What type of interview uses open-ended questions and free flowing conversation?
column17: An unstructured interview
column18: Helen in HR is interviewing five applicants today. She will ask each of them the same job related and situational questions and record the answers. What type of interview is Helen giving?
column21: An interviewer has just given outstanding scores to an average applicant who followed several very poor applicants. What type of interviewing pitfall has the interviewer fallen into?
column23: Contrast effect

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: An HR manager is trying to determine what qualifications the candidates have in order to best serve the company. It is clear that the CV of several candidates are excellent, and it is now the HR manager's job to decide which of them will be invited to participate in face-to-face interviews. The remaining candidates' information will be stored in a database for possible future opportunities with the company. Why is this an example of application review?
column11: The HR manager is deciding which of the candidates will remain in the database for future opportunities
column12: Which of the following will provide an employer with relevant information about the candidates, like personal hygiene, timeliness and manners?
column14: Conducting Interviews
column15: What is the proper course of action when an employer is performing background checks and discovers that a candidate has provided information in his employment application that is untrue?
column17: The employer has grounds to rescind the job offer
column18: Which of the following is the LAST step in the hiring process?
column20: Sending a candidate for a health check.
column21: Which of the following is NOT a step used by a human resources manager to determine the best possible fit for a job?
column23: Review job applications

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of the following is the difference between downsizing and turnover?
column11: Downsizing is planned while turnover can be unplanned and create gaps
column12: A successful architectural design firm is expanding its business and needs to hire three architects and five project managers in the next two months. The human resources department is already tied up with other critical staffing projects. Which of the following would BEST suit the firm's recruitment needs?
column14: Posting ads on online job boards
column15: Although downsizing saves a company money in salary and benefits, which of the following can be a disadvantage of this practice?
column17: The remaining employees become overworked
column18: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of promoting internal candidates into new positions?
column20: The promotion creates a gap in staffing
column21: Felicia manages the training department. She notices that Adam, the training assistant, is bored performing the same, repetitive tasks and often has idle time throughout the day. Adam's low morale concerns Felicia since he is a good employee. Which of the following actions would BEST address this situation?
column23: Redesign Adam's job responsibilities and tasks

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Tom is an HR specialist. He is determining what tasks his company needs to perform in order to accomplish its goals. What is Tom doing?
column11: Job analysis
column12: What does performance standardization allow you to do?
column14: Create a specific definition of the knowledge, skills, and duties for each position
column15: James is an HR specialist. He is determining what tasks need to be performed, how the tasks should be performed and how these tasks relate to other tasks in his company. What is James doing?
column17: Job design
column18: Jack and Diane are two mail clerks for a large corporation. They have the same job responsibilities and are judged by the same performance standards. This is an example of:
column21: Why is performance standardization important?
column23: It allows a company to appraise employee performance against the position's standard and against employees in similar positions.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Mary is an HR specialist who needs to consider the importance of each job to the organization when she determines compensation for the jobs. Which type of job evaluation method is Mary using?
column11: Job ranking
column12: Henry is an HR specialist who has divided all of the jobs in the company into six broad classes, some of which have grades within each class. Which job evaluation method is Henry using?
column14: None of the answers are correct
column15: Janice is a HR specialist engaged in job evaluation applying the same five general factors to each job. Which job evaluation method is Janice using?
column17: Point-factor rating
column18: James is an HR specialist that is evaluating jobs in different clusters by assigning values to each compensable factor for each job in the cluster. Which job evaluation method is James using?
column21: What's the best description of job evaluation?
column23: Assessing the relative value of jobs in an organization

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which of the following is the process used to determine the duties of a job and the qualifications required to perform it?
column11: Quantitative assessment
column12: The minimum qualifications and traits that a person needs in order to perform the duties of a specific position are contained in a _____.
column14: job specification
column15: What is the difference between a job description and a position description?
column17: A job description describes tasks and activities, while a position description summarizes what an employee does.
column18: Tiffany is preparing a written statement that summarizes a set of activities, duties and responsibilities related to the achievement of an organization's goals. This statement is referred to as a _____.
column21: Audrey wants to compose a description of tasks, duties, and responsibilities that will be undertaken by one specific employee. Which document should she use?
column23: Position description

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Why might a company need to reengineer jobs for continuous improvement?
column11: In order to remain an industry leader.
column12: Dale was hired into a company's management associate program straight out of college. As part of the program, Dale will spend the first two years of his employment cycling through different divisions and functional areas of the company, in order to gain a better understanding of the company and how the different units work together. This is known as:
column14: Job enlargement
column15: Which of the following is NOT a key method of reengineering?
column17: Micromanaging employees to ensure their workload is sufficient.
column18: Joseph is a massage therapist who works in a spa while studying sales and marketing at college. Joseph's manager at the spa is hoping to retain him after he earns his college degree and has asked him to use his new skills to assemble ideas for a promotional campaign that will increase the number of clients that visit the spa. Joseph is happy to have new job responsibilities that incorporate what he is learning at school. He has been given the authority to make the necessary decisions to follow the promotional campaign through to its completion. This is known as:
column21: Anthony is working in a sales position at his company and started out performing two activities for his job. Recently, Anthony has had three additional activities added to his role, so that he now performs five job activities that belong to the same hierarchy level in the organization. This is known as:
column23: Job enlargement

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which job redesign strategy encourages respect for coworkers doing other jobs ?
column11: Job rotation
column12: How might job redesign benefit an employee?
column14: It will mean better working conditions.
column15: How does job enrichment differ from job enlargement?
column17: Job enrichment provides additional responsibility and authority; job enlargement just adds extra tasks
column18: Maria is a teller at a bank. She was recently given the task of helping customers with the paperwork for opening checking accounts. This is an example of _____.
column21: How might job rotation benefit a company?
column23: It provides employees with a broader perspective on how the organization operates as a whole.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Ed, an executive, believes he has a great group of employees. He would like to let the employees have more control over how they do their jobs. Which job enrichment method should Ed use?
column11: Job redesign
column12: What are the three ways to provide empowerment?
column14: Job redesign, quality work circles, and teams.
column15: Sally, a supervisor, has been getting lots of feedback lately from employees about the business. She would like to get these suggestions on an ongoing basis. Which job enrichment method should Sally use?
column17: Quality work circles
column18: Which of these is the best strategy for improving motivation and retaining employees?
column21: Mark, a manager, has seen many changes to the production methods in his department. He believes his employees may be unsure about their new tasks and require help. Which job empowerment method can Mark use to BEST address this issue?
column23: Teams

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: To increase productivity, Mary has decided to design a job to match the traits of her most talented employees. This job design approach is known as _____.
column11: Job Characteristic Theory
column12: All of the following are characteristics of job design EXCEPT _____.
column14: Provides salary and benefit information
column15: Which of the following is a potential problem with the job enrichment approach?
column17: The employee can become overwhelmed with responsibilities
column18: John is concerned that the workers in his manufacturing plant will become bored with their jobs, due to performing the same task over and over. Which job design approach might John take to provide variety to workers?
column21: What are the four approaches to job design?
column23: Scientific Management, Job Enlargement/Job Rotation, Job Specialization and the Job Characteristic Theory

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Mary allows her employees plenty of leeway in how they do their jobs and expects them to motivate themselves to be high achievers. She sets the standard by coming in early and working as hard as they do. The self fulfilling prophecies predict that her employees _____
column11: will motivate themselves and achieve the goals she sets.
column12: Joe thinks that his workers hate their job and only come to work to earn their paychecks. However, he is satisfied with their creativity and imagination when they work on projects. Is Joe a typical Theory X manager?
column14: No, because he believes in their creativity and imagination.
column15: Which of the following is credited with the development of the Theory X and Theory Y?
column17: Douglas McGregor
column18: Rebecca runs a research department with specific goals for new product ideas. She lets employees work on their own new product ideas every Friday with little supervision. Rebecca is practicing _____ management.
column21: Mike is a Theory X manager. Which of these does he assume about his employees ?
column23: They would rather be told what to do instead of directing themselves

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Carley works for a company in the Human Resources department. She is concerned about the company's oversight of their employees' personal development and motivation. She is hoping to help the company grow in this area. Based on Carley's concerns, we can determine she is a supporter of the _____.
column11: Human Relations Movement
column12: The human relations movement _____.
column14: focuses on the person as an individual and analyzes what motivates and cultivates his or her achievement in a work setting
column15: Who is the father of the human relations movement?
column17: Elton Mayo
column18: Which sentence describes the Hawthorne Effect?
column20: Attention makes workers feel important and results in better output.
column21: What are the three key elements of the human relations movement?
column23: Work conditions, upward communication, and leadership

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Tom is one of the highest ranked managers at an information technology company. He is allowing a project to continue because it was his idea to launch that line of products, although he now sees that the company could lose a lot of money if it moves forward. Tom doesn't want to admit that he was wrong because he fears for his job. Which principle of management does this concern?
column11: Subordination of Individual Interests to the General Interest
column12: How does the view of Henri Fayol on management and productivity differ from that of Frederick Winslow Taylor?
column14: Taylor believed in a scientific approach while Fayol believed in an administrative approach focusing on management.
column15: A CEO of a small company has implemented a strategy where all employees do their work together, without doing specific assignments all the time. He hopes that it will decrease the level of paperwork necessary and improve employee relations. Which one of Fayol's principles did he violate?
column17: Division of Labor
column18: Which of the following is NOT one of Fayol's first seven Principles of Management?
column21: XYZ Corporation follows the administrative school of management; managers are taught that one of their important roles is
column23: coordinating.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: Which answer best describes the principle of order?
column11: The workplace facilities must be clean, tidy, and safe for employees.
column12: Why did Henri Fayol develop the 14 Principles of Management?
column14: To provide managers with the right tools to manage workers in an effective way.
column15: How could a manager at XYZ Corporation explain the scalar chain to her employees?
column17: By using the aid of an organization chart.
column18: Which of these would be an example of the owner of James Small Engine Repair implementing the principle of equity?
column20: Letting female employees take one month of leave after the birth of a child.
column21: Why would a manager at XYZ Corporation be concerned about the stability of her personnel?
column23: Turnover disrupts the work and interferes with specialization.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: How would an automobile assembly line use Taylor's four principles to increase productivity and efficiency?
column11: Use a precise, specific approach for completing tasks rather than general guidelines.
column12: Which of the following is NOT one of Taylor's four principles of scientific management?
column14: Managers should pay employees based on effort and level of productivity.
column15: Why was Frederick Taylor dissatisfied with systematic management processes?
column17: He felt that systematic processes resulted in too much time being spent training workers.
column18: How should work be planned according to Fredrick Taylor's principles of scientific management?
column20: Managers are responsible for planning the work.
column21: How does Frederick Taylor's principles of scientific management approach the recruitment and training of workers?
column23: Workers should be recruited and trained according to the specific job they will hold.

column1: Level 5 - Introduction to Human Resources Management
column9: How does classical scientific management theory improve production efficiency?
column11: By creating specialized work processes and workforce skills

column9: Suppose a candy store wants to try online marketing to promote its new birthday party discount program and save money on advertising. Which marketing technique would be the most appropriate for the store to use?
