column21: How does controlling in an international environment differ from controlling in a national environment?
column23: The international environment is more complicated because you have to take into account the more complex labor laws, accounting statements, and other issues the manager has to adapt to.

column9: How should a company focus on customer needs?
column11: By giving huge amounts of money to charity and having a PR strategy that displays they care about society itself rather than the customer's expectations.
column12: Why did the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) primarily develop their standards?
column14: Because it wanted to break down international trade barriers.
column15: Which of the following is NOT one of the key principles of ISO 9000?
column17: Strategic approach to management
column18: An IT company focuses strongly on the satisfaction of their employees and that their talents are utilized. Leadership is focused in such a way that it develops a fully-involved staff. The company generally approaches all work as a process by defining work activities and assigning responsibility and accountability to employees. They also stress that each process is unique and not connected with other processes. Identify why this company does NOT fully conform to the ISO 9000.
column20: Because the processes cannot be viewed independently.
column21: A small company wants to be ISO 9000 accredited. They have not yet prepared their quality management system nor trained their employees thoroughly, but they have provided a plan for doing so in the next three years. They have conducted an audit of the organization's quality manual, policies and procedures, and systems. In doing so, they discovered some problems, but they have implemented a strategy to fix these issues. Why will the company FAIL its ISO 9000 accreditation?
column23: Because the company did not prepare their quality system.

column9: Teddy's Tacos recently implemented a TQM system using the managerial decision making areas mentioned by Juran. Top management has implemented a training program that assures the employees make a quality taco. How can management determine that the tacos being made are meeting the required quality standards?
column11: Through Quality Control
column12: How did Crosby define quality?
column14: Quality was conformity to industry or organizational standards.
column15: Which of the following steps is NOT part of Deming's TQM philosophy?
column17: Evaluate
column18: Why did the quality of Japanese automobiles improve after WWII?
column21: Which of the following is NOT one of Crosby's Four Absolutes of Quality Management?
column23: Non-conformance to quality standards prevents waste.

column9: Processes and systems are developed during a company's implementation of Total Quality Management (TQM). Which of the following statements best describes these processes and systems?
column11: All of the answers are incorrect
column12: Which of the following is NOT a reason for a company to implement Total Quality Management (TQM)?
column14: Middle management is not conducive to change at a company that has high customer satisfaction and employee engagement
column15: When a company decides to implement Total Quality Management (TQM), which of the following lists portray the correct order of the steps that are involved?
column17: Coming up with the company's objectives, values, mission, and vision
column18: Which type of objectives are considered when implementing Total Quality Management (TQM)?
column20: Objectives in all areas of the business
column21: Total Quality Management (TQM) involves which of the following?
column23: All of the answers are correct

column9: Identify which of the following is NOT a component of an organization's total quality management.
column11: The CEO of a competing company
column12: Why is it important to use various media sources for marketing when a company is in the phase of focusing on the customer?
column14: It helps the customer make an informed decision after he/she has made a purchase.
column15: The company you work for wants to develop a strategic approach to improvement. In order to do so, it is considering how all processes in the company function and how to test the quality of their product. Your company is also considering launching a new line of products. Why is this an example of a strategic approach to improvement?
column17: Because they are developing a process to test the quality of their product
column18: An airline has employed an IT company to optimize their web service. In the airline's web service, you can purchase your ticket, as well as check in for your flight and purchase additional luggage space. Which of the following is essential if the company is in the phase of producing quality work the first time?
column20: Monitoring the web service and checking whether the customers are actually purchasing services or just browsing
column21: A large company is having trouble with the IRS because it seems that they have not paid enough taxes. Accounting says that they have done their job right, but that retail failed to disclose all of the new contracts. Retail and acquisition reported that they did all they could have, but that the procedure accounting set up was far too long and filled with needless bureaucracy. Identify the main problem this company is facing:
column23: Lack of inter-departmental cooperation

column9: Why do the decisions of middle-level management impact profitability?
column11: Because they are in charge of implementing the strategic plans.
column12: Which of the following best defines productivity?
column14: The relationship between the amount of outputs and amount of inputs needed to produce a product.
column15: Annie is a lower-level manager who oversees daily production and scheduling. Which of the following issues should she watch out for to ensure there is not a negative impact on profitability?
column17: Work stoppage due to faulty production equipment
column18: Tom is a manager at a large firm. He has worked for the firm for a very long time and has spent much of his time focusing on the company's budget. Aside from that, he is also responsible for determining the 10-year goals of the company, one of which, is that every employee needs to have access to healthcare. Why is Tom an example of a top-level manager?
column20: Because he is responsible for designing the long-term company strategy.
column21: How can quality negatively impact profitability?
column23: Quality can only increase profitability.

column9: Your company is trying to determine how competitive it is in the market, and it wants to design the strategic goals of the company. Company A is a company that is just as good as your company, while Company B is a much larger company that can be considered a leader of the industry with far greater revenue than yours. Which company should you compare your company with in the case of best practices benchmarking?
column11: Compare with company B because you want to compare yourself to the leader of the industry.
column12: What do companies use benchmarking for?
column14: Companies use benchmarking as a way to help become more competitive.
column15: John works for a large company that is trying to assess its business through benchmarking. He has been developing surveys and has been told to contact representatives of other companies to seek cooperation. Which stage of benchmarking is John's company in?
column17: Planning and research
column18: How does SWOT differ from peer benchmarking?
column20: SWOT focuses on strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats in the environment while peer benchmarking focuses on organizations of a similar size to yours.
column21: You own a roofing company and wonder how your average prices compare to your competition. You find the average roof prices charged for a 1,500 square foot ranch home and compile the data below. Which of the following is true based on the data you collected?
column23: Your company is priced competitively being both below the average and having only one other company with a cheaper price.

column9: What must be done before a PERT analysis can take place?
column11: Determine the tasks that will be assigned to a particular project and organize them into the longest and shortest anticipated times
column12: Pessimistic Time is defined as _____.
column14: The maximum possible time required to accomplish a task, assuming everything goes wrong (but excluding major catastrophes)
column15: Joe's supervisor has asked how long it will take for him to finish a project. Joe anticipates a 'best case' scenario of 4 hours, a 'worst case' scenario of 8 hours, and a 'probable' scenario of 5 hours. Using the formula to calculate 'Expected Time', Joe should tell his supervisor the project will take _____.
column17: 5.3 hours
column18: Optimistic Time is defined as _____.
column20: The minimum possible time required to accomplish a task, assuming everything proceeds better than is normally expected
column21: What does PERT stand for?
column23: Program Evaluation and Review Technique

column9: You work in an IT company that, so far, has only produced relatively cheap computers. Your company is trying to decide whether or not to introduce a new line of products. Why would a decision tree be useful?
column11: It would help you process important information if an economic crisis were to occur.
column12: If we have an investment of $25,000, and will save $5,000 a year due to that investment, what is the payback time frame in years?
column15: Why are simulations useful?
column17: Because they allow employees to display an emergency scenario without the consequences.
column18: Which of the following best defines payback analysis?
column20: An analysis tool that takes into account investments and anticipated savings or cost increases that will result from that investment
column21: Why do managers use decision-making tools?
column23: To help them choose the best course of action.

column9: Jane, the CEO of a pharmaceutical company, has delegated the task of determining whether the firm should launch a new line of obesity-reducing pills. She instructs her subordinate to 1) assess the firm's current situation, 2) define all of the relevant variables, and 3) focus only on the issue of launching a new line when weighing any risks associated with the uncertainty of the outcome. What was unusual about this approach to weighing risk?
column11: Jane instructed her subordinate to focus on only one issue, without taking a look at the other possible issues.
column12: Which of the following are we trying to determine when we talk about weight risk?
column14: The certainty of a project's outcome
column15: One of the biggest mistakes a manager can make is to _____.
column17: have a sense of certainty and not look at any risk
column18: In which one of the following scenarios did the manager NOT have the proper motivation for making an informed decision?
column20: A manager invests in a firm without research to prove that he does not need to research in order to make a good call.
column21: You run one of the departments in a large company that works in government bonds, futures, and other financial papers. One of your coworkers is being tasked with deciding whether or not to invest in an African country that has had a civil war recently, and has been mostly closed off to the media. What would you advise that he do first as he prepares to make his decision?
column23: Research

column9: A company wants to offer a new line of luxury products. This line is worth at least five million dollars. Which answer represents a potential alternative that the company could pursue instead?
column11: All the answers are correct.
column12: A firm that works in marketing is using the decision-making process to decide on a new PR strategy. They have reached the final stage. What are they MOST likely trying to do?
column14: Implement a weekly system for budget review.
column15: John, a CEO of a company, is trying to fix certain aspects of his company. He started by thinking about what factors prevent the company from growing. He then started developing potential alternatives for his company. Why should John stop and start over?
column17: Because he needed to define his company's problem before doing anything else.
column18: Which of the following is the last step to occur in the decision-making process?
column20: Establish a control and evaluation system.
column21: A department manager is trying to make a decision about a new line of products. He just finished determining limiting factors. What should he do next?
column23: Identify possible alternative strategies for issuing a new line of products.

column9: How are globalization and diversity similar?
column11: They both display trends of the growing integration of culture.
column12: How does technology differ from the other functions of management?
column14: It is by far the function that moves at the quickest pace.
column15: Which of the following is NOT one of the key functions of management?
column17: Innovate
column18: A department manager is perceived by his employees to lack any business ethic. How will that impact his leadership?
column20: Negatively, because he may lose the respect of his employees.
column21: A development team at a large global technology company sells antivirus systems and offers a 10-year warranty for its bestselling water-resistant laptops and mobile phones. The team has just developed a new interactive website to market its products online. Which of the following would most likely be considered an innovation?
column23: The website to market the products

column9: What's the best explanation of the difference between a goal and an objective?
column11: A goal is something that you wish to accomplish in the long-term, while an objective is a short-term goal that helps you accomplish a long-term goal
column12: What step involves you setting goals and objectives?
column14: Action plan development
column15: Which one of the following is not one of the four elements of strategy design?
column17: Prepare your contingency plans
column18: What are the two steps in the strategy formulation process that you must always be taking at every stage of the process?
column21: What does SWOT stand for?
column23: Strategic worldviews provide opportunities and reduce threats

column9: A company is performing an analysis of its environment. It has detected that one of its greatest threats is the potential rise of inflation by 3%. The other two factors that impact it are that there might be a change in fiscal policy that will decrease the effective tax rate by 15% and that Republicans might lose their majority in Congress, creating a complicated political climate. Identify which of the factors mentioned are economic factors:
column11: The increase of inflation by 3%.
column12: Which of the following is a possible way to assemble a strategy?
column14: All of these answers are correct
column15: Why do you need to identify key deliverables?
column17: Because they are essential in the monitor and evaluate segment to ensure that everything is on track.
column18: You work in a small company that is currently in the planning process. Which of the following steps will you start with?
column21: What are the main components of the strategic management process?
column23: Environmental scanning, assemble a strategy, implement the strategy and monitor and evaluate the strategy.

column9: Why do unions and company management enter into collective bargaining?
column11: To jointly come to agreement on workplace issues.
column12: Sammy Slugger the famous baseball player is having contentious negotiations with his team ownership about what he should be paid next year. column14: The two sides will go on arguing because arbitrator's rulings don't need to be followed
column15: Sammy Slugger the famous baseball player is having contentious negotiations with his team ownership about what he should be paid next year. The Baseball Commissioner has called for an arbitrator to end the dispute, the arbitrators ruling will be binding. What does this mean for Sammy and the owner?
column17: The arbitrator will determine Sammy's new salary
column18: Which of these best describes the negotiating step of the collective bargaining process ?
column20: The two sides make offers and counteroffers
column21: Which of these best describes the proposal step of the collective bargaining process ?
column23: Both sides do research into the last labor dispute
column24: Why do most strikes occur ?
column26: Because the union does not feel satisfaction with the negotiations

column9: Non-exempt employees who receive wages are paid _____.

column14: a benefit

column23: A slightly more flexible schedule

column9: The CEO of XYZ Corp. will be conducting reviews with his top managers. He has asked them to get feedback from lower level supervisors and outside vendors with whom they work. Which method is the CEO using to review his top managers?

column14: It raises company morale.

column9: Who enforces employment discrimination laws relating to hostile work environments?

column23: Order an employer to pay an employee damages

column9: Which of the following statements is inaccurate regarding sexual harassment?
column11: It is a form of unwanted sexual advances and may be illegal, but only if it's against the company's policy.

column17: Employee's personal email account accessed on employer's computer
column18: Which of the following are methods that employers use to monitor employees?
column20: All of these options are correct

column23: All of these options are correct

column9: Using hands-on training while working alongside an experienced worker is called _____.
column11: unstructured on-the-job training
column12: Juan is a newly hired assembler at Speedy Cellular. He will spend his first week with Juanita, a veteran assembler, who will work side by side with Juan, showing him each step of the assembly process as he assembles the phones. Why is this an example of on-the-job training?

column14: Problem-Solving Training
column15: Problem-solving training will teach employees to do all of the following, EXCEPT:

column23: work effectively with people who are different

column12: Which of these would be a quick action that would aid in keeping current clients?
column14: Send surveys to current clients
column15: A manager finds her employees are unfamiliar with the mission and vision of the organization. What type of training will solve the problem?
column17: Organizational culture training
column18: Which of the following should be reviewed when assessing training needs?

column23: Take an inventory of what is presently being done

column9: At the beginning of new employee orientation, the employee is told about the company's:
column11: History, code of ethics and purpose

column14: Vacation and time off
column15: The benefits to a company that has an effective employee orientation program include:
column17: Lower turnover since employees are less likely to quit
column18: Typical trainings a new employee will receive during new employee orientation include:
column20: How to set up email and computer passwords
column21: The job description includes:
column23: A list of duties and responsibilities

column9: Which of the following is NOT a step used by a human resources manager to determine the best possible fit for a job?
column11: Perform a detailed check of the candidates' regular contacts
column12: Which of the following will provide an employer with relevant information about the candidates, like personal hygiene, timeliness and manners?

column15: An HR manager is trying to determine what qualifications the candidates have in order to best serve the company. It is clear that the CV of several candidates are excellent, and it is now the HR manager's job to decide which of them will be invited to participate in face-to-face interviews. The remaining candidates' information will be stored in a database for possible future opportunities with the company. Why is this an example of application review?
column17: The HR manager is determining which candidates have the qualifications needed for the job

column9: Which of the following is the difference between downsizing and turnover?
column11: Downsizing is linked to greater productivity for the company while turnover rarely yields good results
column12: A successful architectural design firm is expanding its business and needs to hire three architects and five project managers in the next two months. The human resources department is already tied up with other critical staffing projects. Which of the following would BEST suit the firm's recruitment needs?
column14: Using an employment agency
column15: Felicia manages the training department. She notices that Adam, the training assistant, is bored performing the same, repetitive tasks and often has idle time throughout the day. Adam's low morale concerns Felicia since he is a good employee. Which of the following actions would BEST address this situation?
column17: Redesign Adam's job responsibilities and tasks

column21: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of promoting internal candidates into new positions?
column23: The promotion creates a gap in staffing

column9: Mark from accounting has prepared a budget that has the salaries of all of the workers, rent and office utilities that are essential to the company, as well as how many products his company expects to sell. Why is this NOT an example of an administration budget?
column11: It shouldn't have how many products his company expects to sell.
column12: Which of the following is usually the first budget?
column14: A sales budget
column15: Which of the following is included in a production budget?
column17: Non-production overhead
column18: A manager has reported that he will have to go a little bit off budget in order to be able to order some more office supplies. How will the accounting of the company respond to that?
column20: It won't be a problem because it's only a variance to the budget that should be reported so they can be more accurate next year.
column21: Why is receiving feedback for the budget important?
column23: Because it is important to consult managers on what can be done to increase productivity

column9: Tom works in accounting, and he has to prepare a budget that will take into account all of the activities of the company. There will be a strong investment from the acquisitions department that will impact their budget but is worth less than 2% of the company's value. Should Tom wait for a new report from the acquisition's department?
column11: He should because this is an example of a master budget which is a comprehensive view of the company from a financial standpoint.
column12: Why is financial feasibility an important step in financial planning?

column15: Financial planning can best be defined as a process for making sure that _____.

column18: After allocating the resources, a company CEO is trying to control and monitor the acquisition, allocation and utilization of the financial resources. Should the CEO even perform financial control?
column20: She DOES need to because she must ensure that they are done in accordance regulations and with the plan, and for possible SEC reports.
column21: What type of budget provides an estimation of costs and revenue regarding a long-term business venture or fixed asset?

column9: Why can flexible budgeting cause problems?
column11: It has no negative effects that have been discovered thus far.
column12: Which of the following is NOT a function of a budget?
column14: To determine an organization's financial future based on market trends
column15: How does zero-based budgeting differ to top-down budgeting?
column17: Zero-based budgeting doesn't take into account the previous year's performance or actual results, while top-down does.
column18: A CEO of a company and a few members of upper management decided on the budget for the company and have stated there will be no changes in it based on feedback from their subordinates. In which of the following cases is such an action a good idea?

column21: Why can bottom-up budgeting be a good idea?
column23: Because the lower management can make the plans based on the needs of specific departments.

column9: If your company's assets are $100,000 while it's shareholders' equity is $70,000, what is the value of your company's liabilities?
column12: If the revenue of a company is $100,000, its gross profit $70,000, and its expenses $20,000, what is the company's net profit/loss?
column15: What is the end product of the accounting cycle?
column17: A financial statement
column18: On a balance sheet, assets are equal to what?
column21: What is generated by comparing multiple financial statements?
column23: Financial ratios

column9: Mary and Kelly have just started working for a new boss. Mary is unhappy because the new boss is strict and has many new rules. Kelly is optimistic because the office feels organized and has direction now under the new boss. Mary and Kelly have different _____
column11: perceptions.
column12: Tad was tasked with hiring a new sales manager for his team. He had two equally qualified candidates with personalities that seemed alike. However, he found Cathy to be more attractive than Kelly. Tad decided to hire Cathy because he felt she would get along better with the team than Kelly would. Tad's behavior is an example of _____
column14: attribution.
column15: What does attribution theory suggest about how we assess the behavior of others?
column17: We attempt to determine whether the behavior is caused by internal or external factors
column18: Donald is an office manager. In his youth, he found that other kids of a certain nationality were quarrelsome and hard to get along with. When an applicant from the same nationality applied for an opening in Donald's office, Donald dismissed him because he didn't feel the applicant would get along with existing staff. Donald is using _____
column21: Joe is a top salesman, something he attributes to his own intelligence, personality and wit. When he recently missed a monthly quota though, he blamed it on new competitors in his territory. Joe is rationalizing his failure by using _____
column23: self-serving bias.

column9: Why is arbitration considered the most aggressive third-party intervention?

column12: Jane and Thomas are disputing over methods for advancing their company's image. The mediator maintains an impartial stance and keeps extensive notes that she presents to Jane and Thomas to resolve their conflict. Which of these in this scenario is NOT common for mediators?
column14: The mediator keeping written records.

column20: Because the parties involved cannot reach an agreement themselves.
column21: How does the role of the facilitator differ from that of the mediator?

column12: Which of the following is a profile of a person likely to use accommodation as a conflict management style?
