column15: Which of these conflict management styles attempts to resolve a conflict by finding a middle ground?
column17: Compromise
column18: Jonathan and Sam are employed at a PR company in Boston. Both of them want the company to fund projects they've been working on for the past three years, but senior management has informed them that the company will only fund one of the projects. Which one of the following options best explains why this situation resulted in competition?
column20: The objective of each party was to win at the other party's expense, regardless of the cost.
column21: Mark from the IT sector and Wayne from the accounting sector are supposed to develop a strategy that will accommodate the long-term needs of the company. Mark thinks they need to buy the best computers on the market, while Wayne wants them to pick the cheapest. After an open disagreement, Mark has taken a 2-week leave in order to not have to disagree about the issue again. Which of the following best describes this conflict resolution style?
column23: Avoidance

column9: Organizational communication should be used to communicate which of the following pieces of information?
column11: All the answers are correct
column12: The manager of a company wants to inform his employees that they will not receive a high holiday bonus because revenue is down by 5%. He doesn't want to use formal methods of communication because if the information leaks it would further harm the company's stock, but he is sympathetic towards his employees and wants them to be able to plan their finances. Which method of communication should he use?
column14: The grapevine
column15: Thomas from marketing and James from accounting have been appointed to formulate the company's new PR strategy. They are both heads of a department, and the upper management wants them to cooperate in forming this new strategy. Why is their discussion of a new strategy an example of horizontal communication?
column17: Because they are of the same rank in managerial hierarchy
column18: In which of the following scenarios should external communication be utilized?
column20: When a company wants to communicate with its stakeholders
column21: Mark is not satisfied with how his employer, Johnson Electronics, distributes products to customers. He believes that the process is inefficient and costs far too much. He has some ideas as to how the distributing cost could be decreased. Mark would like to share his ideas with his superiors. Which form of communication is best suited for such a situation?
column23: Upward communication

column9: Why do managers rely heavily on oral communication?
column11: To avoid inconsistencies between oral communication and nonverbal communication
column12: Which type of communication may be related to someone's physical appearance?
column14: Nonverbal communication
column15: Why is interpersonal communication considered to be minimally restricted?
column17: Individuals engaged in it share some level of familiarity with each other
column18: All of the following are types of communication successful managers use EXCEPT:
column21: How does written communication provide immediacy and economical feasibility?
column23: Messages are communicated quickly and with no travel expenses.

column9: Sender is to encode as receiver is to _____.
column11: decipher
column12: The communication process is made up of _____.
column14: sender, channel, receiver
column15: How does understanding occur in a communication process?
column17: When each party can agree on what was being communicated without the need for inferences or assumptions.
column18: A continued dialogue between the sender & receiver is called _____.
column21: Which of the following illustrates the difference between psychological noise and physiological noise?
column23: Psychological noise occurs when you have a hard time understanding the words of a message, while physiological noise occurs when you cannot understand the grammatical structure of a message.

column9: Which of the following should a manager consider when communicating in a business environment?
column11: All the answers are correct
column12: Which of the following will likely cause understandable awareness of expectations and performance measurements for all employees?
column14: An open and clear communication climate
column15: Which of the following management functions occurs when a manager reviews and reports job performance and, if necessary, takes corrective and preventive actions?
column17: Controlling
column18: In a company, communication is vital towards achieving _____.
column21: A new manager who is very informal has started sending text messages and e-mails to his employees during out-of-work hours when they would like to be with their families. The previous manager and the company itself are very formal and there is usually very little communication between the workers outside of regular working hours and the communication is always face-to-face. Which of the following does the new manager need to conform to?
column23: The personal space of the employees

column9: Which shift is NOT an example of a compressed workweek?
column11: 9 hour shift for 4 days + 4 hour shift for 1 day
column12: Why would Manny the manager consider alternatives to the typical nine-to-five work schedule for his employees?
column14: To help his employees to find a better balance between work and life
column15: How has job flexibility impacted organizations?
column17: It has improved employee performance.
column18: Anna is a full-time customer service representative who works from home. Which of these terms describes the job flexibility option that allows an employee to work the majority of their work hours from home or another remote location outside of the office?
column21: Aubrey is researching employers that offer telecommuting as a job flexibility option. Which of the following employee characteristics is NOT ideal for a telecommuting?
column23: Low time management

column9: Empowerment is thought to come from the _____.
column11: employer
column12: When employees are empowered there is _____.
column14: increased motivation and job satisfaction
column15: What could Manny the manager do to motivate employees and increase productivity in the workplace?
column17: Encourage participation in decision making processes
column18: To effectively empower employees, employers must do all of the following EXCEPT:
column21: What should Manny the manager NOT do if he wants to empower his employees?
column23: Promote competition between employees

column9: How does job enrichment differ from job enlargement?
column11: Job enrichment provides additional responsibility and authority; job enlargement just adds extra tasks
column12: Maria is a teller at a bank. She was recently given the task of helping customers with the paperwork for opening checking accounts. This is an example of _____.
column14: job enlargement
column15: How might job redesign benefit an employee?
column17: It will make a job more interesting.
column18: Which job redesign strategy encourages respect for coworkers doing other jobs ?
column21: How might job rotation benefit a company?
column23: It provides employees with a broader perspective on how the organization operates as a whole.

column9: Employees who are _____ motivated tend to work at higher levels of productivity and strive to develop professionally.
column11: intrinsically
column12: A company has stated that its organizational goal is to increase customer care quality. David, an employee in the marketing division, has created a new software that helps the company achieve that, and the customers are very satisfied with his work. Why should he be rewarded?
column14: Because he helped the company in achieving its organizational goal.
column15: How do extrinsic rewards differ from intrinsic rewards?
column17: Intrinsic rewards are self-administered, while extrinsic rewards are offered by a supervisor or manager.
column18: Which of the following is an example of an extrinsic reward?
column20: A worker did a very good job and will be given more meaningful work.
column21: Thomas is an employee who has helped his IT company increase its revenue by 5% in the first quarter. The company CEO has asked the head of the HR department how they could best provide Thomas with an intrinsic reward. Which of the following is a likely response by the head of the HR department?
column23: You should give him more meaningful work, that might help him be more productive.

column9: Which of the following does NOT occur with goal commitment?
column11: Goals are important to the employee
column12: Locke's goal setting theory states that goals should have all of the following elements, EXCEPT:
column14: Ease of attainment
column15: Directing a contractor to lay floor tile in a Versailles pattern with a half-inch grout joint is an example of:
column17: Providing a specific goal
column18: Identify the positive feedback message that provides the most specific feedback that could be used by a manager who follows Locke's Goal-Setting Theory.
column20: The cream filling in the cake you just now made is so smooth and delicious!
column21: When task complexity is high, an employee will be:
column23: More motivated

column9: One week, shortly after her mother's death, Sarah arrives at work an hour late on two different occasions. Considering Sarah's personal circumstances, her manager decides to ignore the behavior in the hopes that it will disappear over time. Sarah's manager is using the _____ technique.
column11: negative reinforcement
column12: All of the workers at Ted's Emporium have been shown the cold warehouse where employees who break any of the company rules are sent to work. Just thinking about the possibility of being sent into such a bleak work setting keeps most new employees from even considering breaking a rule. In this situation, management is successfully using the technique of _____ in order to encourage good behavior.
column14: avoidance
column15: Jim's manager catches Jim breaking one of the company rules. He decides that the best course of action will be to take away one of Jim's company privileges as a response. In terms of Thorndike's theory, how is Jim's manager responding to the incident?
column17: He is using punishment in order to decrease the probability of repeated inappropriate behavior on Jim's part.
column18: Which of these techniques is used to reward desirable behavior with the intent of increasing the likelihood that the pleasing behavior will be repeated?
column21: Why would a manager incorporate reinforcement theory in dealing with his or her employees?
column23: In order to influence employee motivation

column9: Identify the three components of expectancy theory.
column11: Expectancy, performance, reward
column12: How would XYZ Corporation implement Vroom's expectancy theory regarding promotions in the company?
column14: By informing employees that promotions are tied to their performance and only promoting the best workers
column15: Which component of Vroom's expectancy theory refers to the level of effort an employee is willing to exert in hopes that the increased effort will result in better performance.
column17: Expectancy
column18: Which person developed expectancy theory?
column21: How can Vroom's expectancy theory be used to explain employee motivation?
column23: Once the relationship between effort and reward is linked in the employee's mind, he will work harder.

column9: Based on the equity theory, which of the following is NOT an example of an output?
column11: Employees having the sense that they have additional autonomy and authority in their work environment.
column12: Why does the equity theory believe that the number of inputs must be equal to the number of outputs?
column14: Because employees will be more productive if this balance occurs.
column15: One of your employees feels like he is not being treated equally in comparison to other workers. He has not voiced that opinion but is constantly trying to make his work seem better in comparison to others. However, you feel that his work is not as good because he isn't trying hard enough. He just requested a transfer from marketing to PR. Which of the following is a usual behavior that this employee did NOT do when he felt that he was not being treated equally?
column17: Asking for more equitable treatment.
column18: A team designing their company's new marketing strategy has shown loyalty by refusing to accept a job offer from a competing firm. They have shown great knowledge, skill and enthusiasm because they have a belief that they are growing as people within their current job. Which of the following from the above scenario is NOT an input?
column21: Who developed the equity theory in 1963?
column23: John Stacey Adams

column9: Tom is the manager of a sales team. Becky is one of his employees with a need for affiliation. What type of work environment would be most beneficial to Becky?
column11: A cooperative team environment
column12: Rachel is applying to business school programs. She has been avoiding schools that do not require an entrance exam, because she thinks the program might not be rigorous enough if they accept too many people. At the same time, she is also avoiding the most elite schools in her area because she is worried those programs will be too challenging. Based on the acquired needs theory, what type of need is strongest for Rachel?
column14: Achievement
column15: Which of these theories is based on the premise that one's needs are acquired over time as a result of their experiences and includes the needs of achievement, power, and affiliation?
column17: McClelland's Acquired Needs Theory
column18: An individual with the _____ will desire agreement and compliance.
column21: Phil is a leader within a political campaign. He has recently been named campaign manager because of his ability to coordinate and motivate his team of people. What type of need does Phil likely have?
column23: Need for institutional power

column9: The 'ERG' in Alderfer's ERG Theory stands for:
column11: existence, relatedness and growth
column12: All of the following are true of Alderfer's ERG theory EXCEPT:
column14: It suggests that in order to satisfy needs, a person must act.
column15: Frustration-regression involves:
column17: a tendency to pursue lower-order needs when higher-order needs are no longer satisfied
column18: If Dennis, top producer at a financial firm, breaks his leg, what need from Alderfer's ERG theory would he likely try to satisfy?
column21: Ginger just got the promotion she has been after for a very long time. She will be in charge of the entire creative division of her company. What need, according to Alderfer's ERG theory, will be satisfied?
column23: Growth need

column9: _____ cause dissatisfaction in the workplace, are extrinsic to the work itself, and linked to compensation and job security.
column11: Progression principles
column12: How did Herzberg develop the two-factor theory?
column14: He interviewed employees to determine what made them feel good and bad about their jobs.
column15: In employee motivation, the opposite of satisfaction is _____.
column17: no satisfaction
column18: _____ are linked to employee motivation and arise from intrinsic conditions of the job itself.
column21: According to Herzberg, how can employee dissatisfaction be reduced while at the same time building employee satisfaction?
column23: By finding the right balance between hygiene factors and motivators.

column9: In Tara's performance review, her boss points out Tara's positive ranking when it comes to meeting deadlines for key projects. In terms of organizational goals, why is sharing this information so important in the performance review?
column11: Tara will probably continue to meet deadlines, since employees typically end up repeating behaviors that they receive positive rankings on.
column12: James has read about the Pygmalion effect and hopes that it can be used to enable growth for his employees, which will ultimately strengthen the organization. Which of these is a commonly used way of communicating expectations that James could use to start the ball rolling with his employees?
column14: Modeling
column15: Which of these is an example of the Pygmalion effect?
column17: Bob stubs his toe getting into the shower and thinks to himself that it's going to be a bad day. The day does turn out bad.
column18: Sandra's boss has a high opinion of her and believes that she has the potential to some day work in management. Which of the following would NOT be involved in Sandra's experience of the Pygmalion effect based on her boss's expectations?
column20: Sandra would take time to investigate the basis for her boss's expectations.
column21: Which of these terms is considered synonymous with the Pygmalion effect?
column23: The self-fulfilling prophecy

column9: An employee's primary needs include _____.
column11: opportunities for achievement
column12: According to the needs-based theory of motivation, employees are more likely to be productive if their _____ needs are met.
column14: Primary and secondary
column15: How can employers use the behavior-based theory of motivation to increase worker output?
column17: Set clear goals with the employee and assign clearly defined tasks.
column18: Which of the following is an example of a situation that would satisfy a secondary need?
column21: Behavior-based motivation says employees can be driven by _____.
column23: opportunities to do meaningful work

column9: Which of the following is NOT correct regarding the attribution theory of leadership?
column11: Individuals interpret events or happenings around them, and this relates to their thinking and behavior.
column12: Which of the following is an example of the Attribution Theory of Leadership?
column14: A leader sees Frank doing great work and decides he is a great employee.
column15: According to the Attribution Theory of Leadership, there are many ways in which an organization might be negatively impacted by a leader's attributions. How might that organization be positively affected?
column17: Employees could be recognized and accurately placed within the organization based on attributions.
column18: Joe seems on edge and is short-tempered with everyone at work. His boss, Leon, thinks that Joe's behavior is caused by the extreme pressure of recent work deadlines and the current staff shortage. Leon is using _____ to explain Joe's behavior.
column21: Jeremy tends to use internal attribution in viewing his employees' behavior. Which of the following would MOST reflect this attribution?
column23: Jeremy thinks that Sarah's snapping at coworkers must be the result of a mental illness.

column9: How does the trait theory of leadership differ from the behavioral theory of leadership?
column11: The trait theory focuses on the characteristics of the leader, while the behavioral theory believes leaders can behave in different ways.
column12: Your team leader has always been a natural communicator. He has performed his job well and he never doubted any of his team members. When working in a stressful environment, he always managed to achieve team coherency. Why is this an example of a trait leader?
column14: Because his traits, such as managing to connect to his team, seem to make him a good leader.
column15: Which of the following is NOT an example of a behavioral theory leader?
column17: An emotional leader
column18: How do democratic leaders significantly differ to laissez-faire leaders?
column20: Democratic leaders leave a lot of open space for their employees, while laissez-faire teams are similar, but with a structured hierarchy.
column21: Why are there opposing views on how the leadership of an organization should be conducted?
column23: Because there is a plurality of perspectives, none of which are necessarily wrong.

column9: John, a manager, is leading his team on a new promotional strategy to make the company best positioned for the acquisition of what used to be a very competitive company. He is trying to determine the skills of his workers, and what are their strengths and weaknesses. Why is this an example of role taking?
column11: Because the company is trying to position itself on the market.
column12: Why is it better to be in the in-group rather than the out-group?
column14: The communication is more directive than give and take.
column15: Team members begin working on projects, and the manager begins to see how devoted they are to the work that needs to be done. What is this process called?
column17: Role making
column18: Which of the following is true in regards to Leader-Member Exchange Theory?
column20: Managers expect employees to work hard, be loyal, and trustworthy.
column21: Jane leads a team that is working in the R&D department, where they focus on developing new lines of products for customers. They are pretty used to working with each other more cohesively, and have given up on establishing some basic norms that they follow because they think it is a waste of time. Why is this NOT an example of routinization?
column23: Because there are no established basic norms.

column9: Sue is a law enforcement officer. She is excellent at gaining confessions from suspects through her persuasive personality and questionable interrogation techniques. Where would Sue likely land on the Mach scale?
column11: High Mach
column12: Which of the following characteristic is common in low Machs?
column14: They are highly submissive.
column15: Which type of Mach flourishes in face-to-face settings where there are limited rules and structure, and emotions hold little value in goal achievement?
column17: High
column18: Grant is a high school student who is taking a math test. The teacher had to step out of the room for an emergency and instructed the class to continue silently taking their tests. One of the other students realizes the teacher left the answer key on his desk and begins passing it around. Grant continues to silently take his test and does not look at the answers when they pass his desk. Where is Grant on the Mach scale?
column21: What type of trait is Machiavellianism?
column23: Personality

column9: When a manager gives specific advice, clarifies expectations, and assigns tasks, he is using which leadership style?
column11: Achievement-oriented leadership.
column12: The manager of a retail store sets a sales goal of over 1,000 pairs of sneakers to be sold in a day, more than any shoe store has ever sold. He rallied the sales team to sell sneakers and encouraged each salesperson during the sales event. This manager was using _____.
column14: achievement-oriented leadership
column15: Path-Goal Theory involves _____.
column17: establishing a supportive plan for goal achievement
column18: Mike is a sales manager who was recently informed of a large account his company will be acquiring this year. He brought this new information up at his monthly meeting so his team could discuss what that might mean for their sales goals this fiscal year. What style of leadership is Mike displaying?
column21: A manager that expresses and shows concern for the well-being of weary employees is using _____.
column23: supportive leadership

column9: Juan never worked as a waiter before. He asked his boss to let him take a few tables. He said he was ready to take on the challenge. Which leadership style would be best for Juan?
column11: Controlling
column12: Clara is a veteran waitress who knows what to do and enjoys her work and chatting with the customers. Which leadership style would be best for Clara?
column14: Delegating
column15: It is Darla's first day at her very first job at the ice cream parlor. Darla does not know anything about how an ice cream parlor is run. Which leadership style would be best for Darla?
column17: Telling
column18: Follower confidence is:
column20: the degree to which a follower feels comfortable performing a task.
column21: Tara is a very good hairdresser. She was asked to style the mayor's hair today. She refused to do it because she was afraid she may make a mistake. Which leadership style would work best with Tara?
column23: Participating
column24: Follower ability means:
column26: the degree to which the follower possesses skills to perform a task.

column9: The Least Preferred Co-worker ranking system is about:
column11: a manager's tendency to lead a certain way
column12: Larry the leader has a low LPC score. Which situation will he work best in?
column14: Situations where success depends on meeting production goals
column15: Tom is a new graduate just appointed to be supervisor. He walks around with a stopwatch timing how quickly tasks are getting done and suggesting improvements. He does not care to get to know his employees. What kind of situation has Tom created?
column17: Power trip
column18: Sarah the supervisor has a high LPC score. How can the regional manager use this in Sarah's job assignments?
column20: By placing her in situations where the ability to make complex decisions is required
column21: Fred the football coach is known as one of the league's best. He explains complex plays in a way that everyone on the team understands. The team members like Coach Fred because he takes a personal interest in each of them and they have confidence that his game strategies will work. Fred has created what type of work situation?
column23: Favorable

column9: Joe was 15 minutes late returning from lunch break today. Jill, his supervisor, tells Joe he must stay 15 minutes extra after work today to make it up. Jill is using _____ power.
column11: influence
column12: Sam is a sales manager at a car dealership. He is instituting a salesperson of the month program where the top seller gets a plaque to hang on their office wall along with a free lunch. Sam is using _____ power.
column14: reward
column15: The main bases of positional power include:
column17: legitimate, coercive, and reward.
column18: Juanita is a manager at the bank. This morning she advised her staff that she wanted all pending credit applications completed and on her desk for review by 3 PM. Juanita is using _____ power.
column21: A key to a manager's success is the ability to use _____ to influence employee behavior.
column23: a combination of personal and positional power

column9: Mr. Rogers has been promoted to a General Manager position at local real estate agency. He has over 30 years experience and is well respected by fellow agents and former customers. Through the company's mentorship program, he is seen as a father figure to a number of the younger agents. How can Mr. Rogers BEST influence the company's agents to respect his authority?
column11: Through coercive power
column12: Which of these power bases is commonly seen in charismatic leaders who are able to invoke a passion for followership due to their magnetic personality?
column14: referent
column15: Which of these power bases is the result of knowing or understanding how to do job-related tasks that subordinates need to know?
column17: expert
column18: Ms. Pauline Powers has been promoted to Divisional Manager at a software development company. Ms. Powers is an internationally recognized expert in the computer language that the company uses. How can Ms. Powers influence her subordinates to respect her authority?
column21: Which type of power is independent from the position a manager holds in an organization and rests solely in the individual in things such as a manager's personality, experience, and special knowledge?
column23: Personal

column9: Tiana is a manager at a software company. She does not concern herself with production or employee needs. The work does not get done, and the employees are miserable. Which type of leader is Tiana?
column11: Impoverished leader
column12: Thomas is a CEO of a large PR company. As a team leader, he believes that _____.
column14: the company must be productive, but it is equally important that its employees are also satisfied with their working conditions
column15: Which of the following is a likely trait of a produce or perish leader?
column17: Authoritarian tendencies.
column18: Which of the following is the most important for a middle-of-the-road leader?
column21: Tom is a manager that allows employees to relax on the job. He often asks questions like, How are you? Is there anything I can do to help? and Are you satisfied with the working conditions here? Why is this an example of a country club leader?
column23: Because he cares about his employees mental state and happiness.

column9: In which of these situations will bureaucratic leadership fail?
column11: When an organization needs to promote change and take risks on a regular basis.
column12: Bureaucratic leadership follows a _____ management philosophy.
column14: by the book
column15: Which of the following scenarios depicts a bureaucratic leader?
column17: Aiden is head of security for a large software company. He is meticulous and carefully handles all security incidents according to the company's policies, rules and procedures.
column18: In which of these situations would a bureaucratic leadership style be most effective?
column20: Samantha supervises an auto service shop. It is her responsibility to ensure the cars her team services are repaired properly and are safe to drive.
column21: Who is considered to have developed the idea of bureaucratic leadership?
column23: Frederick Taylor

column9: Which school of thought produced situational management?
column11: Behaviorist
column12: Which of the following is NOT an example of situational leadership?
column14: Quentin is a project manager who really admires Abraham Lincoln. He studies Lincoln's leadership style and makes a conscious effort to modify his style to match Lincoln's.
column15: Anne coaches girls soccer. This season she is working with teams from two different age groups, one team is for 8-9 year old girls, and the other is for 14-16 year old girls. How can Anne apply situational leadership based on the capacity of the followers?
column17: Anne could provide more specific instruction to the girls on the younger team.
column18: Mike coaches boys baseball. During practice, Mike spends a lot of time working with each of the boys on specific baseball skills. On game day, however, Mike becomes very directive, giving rapid instructions to the boys. This is an example of situational leadership based on the _____.
column21: According to situational theory, _____.
column23: leaders should adjust their behavior depending on circumstances

column9: Charismatic leaders are good role models because they _____.
column11: have impeccable posture
column12: All of the following can occur when a charismatic leader has personal motives EXCEPT:
column14: Allowing subordinates to share in the decision making
column15: Charismatic leaders use their _____ to appeal to followers.
column17: magnetic personalities and charm
column18: The charismatic leader's influence over others is due to his/her _____ power.
column21: Why are subordinates willing to follow a charismatic leader?
column23: Because of how the leader treats them

column9: Drawbacks of the authoritarian style of leadership include all of the following EXCEPT
column11: Autocratic leaders are regarded by subordinates as inferior.
column12: Which of the following scenarios best depicts authoritarian leadership?
column14: Arnold does not trust his employees to work unsupervised. He is constantly interfering in their work to make sure things are completed to his standards.
column15: Autocratic leaders have complete control over
column17: decision making
column18: Autocratic leaders
column20: expect their subordinates to trust that they have come to the best possible decision on their own.
column21: Benefits of the authoritarian style of leadership include all of the following EXCEPT
column23: Autocratic leaders empower their subordinates and are pleasant to work for.

column9: When is the participative/democratic leadership style considered effective?
column11: In a team environment where productivity and efficiency are secondary to quality
column12: Sarita recently transferred to a newly-created learning and innovation department at her company. Her new supervisor leads a team of eight but does all the decision making on new projects. Is the supervisor an effective or ineffective leader and why?
column14: Ineffective; the supervisor does not appear to value his subordinates' input
column15: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a participative/democratic leader?
column17: Focuses on what a subordinate is doing wrong
column18: Employees under a participative/democratic leadership tend to have a high level of _____ and _____.
column21: When is the participative/democratic leadership style ineffective in the workplace?
column23: In a team environment where productivity and efficiency take a back seat to quality

column9: Laissez-faire is a French phrase that translates into:
column11: Leave it be
column12: The laissez-faire leader provides their employee with which of the following?
column14: All of these
column15: At which point will the laissez-faire leader intervene in an employee's work?
column17: At a peer's request
column18: Laissez-faire leadership is most likely to be effective with which of the following groups of employees?
column20: A team of experienced landscapers who have worked together for years and enjoy tackling new projects.
column21: Monitoring employees is a critical activity for the laissez-faire leader for all of the following reasons EXCEPT
column23: it empowers employees by shifting the focus to them and away from the leader.

column9: Which of the following statements is TRUE of philanthropic characteristics in a leader?
column11: It is a testament of character and a requirement of being a true leader
column12: Which of the following is NOT a trait of a servant leader?
column14: Spending more time talking than listening
column15: All of the following are examples of philanthropy EXCEPT:
column17: Feeling good when in the company of others
column18: Pamela is a CEO who makes employees feel special by celebrating and promoting their work activities as well as supporting their professional and personal development. She also treats customers with the utmost care. However, Pamela's behavior toward the company's other executives is dismissive; she does not respect their work ethics. Pamela does NOT exhibit servant leadership because:
column20: Her supportive behavior does not extend to her peers
column21: Which of the following is NOT one of Greenleaf's tenets of leadership?
column23: Before you lead, you must first be a servant

column9: After Mario completes his monthly report, his boss reviews it to see if the standards were met. If there are errors, Mario is told he has to work an extra hour each day for the next two weeks. This is an example of which type of management?
column11: Active management by transaction
column12: Wendy's supervisor constantly monitors her performance closely. He scrutinizes her work for potential problems and quickly jumps in to correct her to prevent additional errors. Which type of management is he exhibiting?
column14: Active management by exception
column15: What is most important to a transactional leader when delivering rewards or punishment to subordinates?
column17: Employee performance
column18: Transactional leadership assumes people are motivated by _____.
column21: Which of the following statements about transactional leaders and the chain of command is FALSE?
column23: The chain of command is based on formal authority and responsibility in the organization

column9: How is vision central to a transformational leader's goal?
column11: Before anyone can follow a leader, they need to have an idea of where they are going and why through vision.
column12: Which of the following scenarios depicts intellectual stimulation?
column14: Whenever John's team is beginning a new project he holds brainstorming sessions, and encourages them to propose new, creative ideas for completing the project.
column15: The transformational leader uses individualized consideration, intellectual stimulation, charisma, and _____ to convince employees to transcend their personal interests for the sake of the larger organization.
column17: idealized influence
column18: What sets the transformational leader apart from many other leadership styles is their ability to influence others to follow them through all of the following, EXCEPT _____.
column21: The transformational leader uses _____ to control how they are viewed by their followers.
column23: charisma

column9: A leader who influences employees to conceptualize the future state of the organization is _____.
column11: motivating employees
column12: A leader can BEST motivate employees by _____.
column14: learning about the employees' needs and wants and recognizing their good work
column15: How do informal and formal leadership roles differ?
column17: Personality traits are more important in informal leadership roles
column18: The CEO of a large company tells his employees what he expects them to do to increase revenue in the next quarter. He specifically explains an algorithm he purchased which should help their company. He gives his employees details on how to use the algorithm and he has a comprehensive list of assignments for them. How is this an example of guiding employees?
column20: The CEO is providing clear instructions on using a new tool in addition to clarifying everyone's role in the process
column21: The membership representatives at a health insurance company have been working hard during a particularly stressful open enrollment. The manager decides to throw a catered lunch for the employees because _____.
column23: it's a gesture of appreciation for their hard work, which helps build morale

column9: How does the lack of any conflict impact the work environment?
column11: It is, without a doubt, great for the work environment as it can be highly productive.
column12: Thomas and Jane are working on a proposal for a new PR strategy for their company. Thomas believes that they should focus on TV ads, while Jane believes they should focus on the world of social media because most other forms of communication are outdated. Identify the kind of conflict in this situation and the reason behind it.
column14: It is a task conflict, because they are proposing alternative methods to achieving the same goal.
column15: Two coworkers are having a dispute about how to achieve the goal of their company, which is to introduce the most competitive product in the smart phones industry. In the heat of the argument, one of the workers calls the other a lazy good-for-nothing. Why is this an example of a people conflict?
column17: Because it was a personal insult not relevant to the task.
column18: Which of the following is a major source of people conflict in teams?
column21: How does a perceptual set of beliefs, values and attitudes influence the behavior of people?
column23: Each individual interprets factual situations in a different manner, which can lead to conflict.

column9: What is a preventative measure that can be taken to reduce the chances of groupthink?
column11: All the answers are correct.
column12: Which of the following describes the likely outcome of decisions shaped by groupthink?
column14: They have a moderate probability of success
column15: The king of a small country wants to go to war. Everyone agrees with him in an attempt to gain his favor, even though they would be attacking a much larger nation. This an example of:
column17: groupthink
column18: Groups that experience groupthink disregard _____ in order to maintain harmony in the group.
column21: Groupthink occurs:
column23: When a group makes faulty or ineffective decisions for the sake of reaching a consensus.

column9: Which of these terms is used to describe a sequence of planned activities aimed at improving teamwork to increase group cohesion and effectiveness?
column11: group enlargement
column12: Which of these terms describes the degree to which group members come together as one unit to reach a common goal?
column14: group cohesion
column15: Which type of team building is aimed at improving the specific teamwork skills which group members need to accomplish their goal and can be immediately applied in the workplace?
column17: skills-based team building
column18: Which of these is not considered a characteristic of cohesive groups?
column21: Which type of team building is used to increase the understanding of who each group member is and how to better communicate with one another?
column23: personality-based team building

column9: Which of these stages represents the time when the group becomes a cohesive unit, morale is high and members actively acknowledge the talents, skills and experience that each member brings to the group?
column11: performing
column12: Which of these stages represent the time characterized with anxiety and uncertainty when the group is just starting to come together?
column14: forming
column15: Jamal, Antonio, Lorraine and Sasha have been assigned to work together on a software development project. Their first few meetings went well. They established a rough schedule for the project and assigned responsibilities for the key tasks. Now, however, their meetings seem to be unproductive and filled with conflict. Sasha and Jamal are continually arguing about which part of the software should be developed first, and Lorraine keeps asking about who is going to present the project plan. Which stage of development is this group in?
column17: storming
column18: Jennifer, Eric, Gabriel and Maria are working together to develop a marketing plan for one of their company's newest product lines. After some initial conflict, the group started to really come together. Now, the group is highly unified and very productive. The marketing plan is practically writing itself! Which stage of development is this group in?
column21: Which of these stages is used to wrap up activities of the group and provide a sense of closure to its members?
column23: adjourning

column9: Why do organizations use work teams?
column11: Work teams offer the benefit of combined experiences, ideas and opinions
column12: Vivian works in housekeeping at a resort hotel. She manages the laundry division and has three dozen valets and laundry attendants reporting directly to her, in addition to six contracted tailors and furniture upholsterers. Why is this a functional work team?
column14: Each team member understands what their role is in relation to the overall operations of the business
column15: How do functional teams differ from self-directed teams?
column17: Members of self-directed teams have significantly more authority than those in functional teams
column18: Which of the following is NOT a type of work team common in contemporary organizations?
column21: Howard is vice president of media relations. Keisha is a senior web developer in marketing. Both are part of a team of high-level employees from various departments that will determine how best to present the company's new line of products to the public. Although each team member has authority over company policy, there is no designated group leader. Why is this a cross-functional team?
column23: Each member lends expertise in their particular field and is empowered to make decisions for the company

column9: Why is having a suitable organizational structure important for the company?
column11: It will allow the company to implement strategic planning to manage immediate needs.
column12: Why is the mechanistic structure often referred to as a bureaucratic structure?
column14: Because the organization has a formal network
column15: Why is it impossible to institute standardized processes and procedures in an organic structure?
column17: Because of the uncertainty of organic organizations
column18: Which of the following is a characteristic of a mechanistic structure?
column21: A state university has a system where most of the decisions are made by the top level of management and the subordinates are not supposed to question them. There are no complex decision-making processes that involve multiple parties and most of the communication goes from the bottom toward the top. Why is this NOT a common mechanistic structure?
column23: Because most of the communication goes from the bottom toward the top

column9: Why is the team organizational structure utilized?
column11: To break down functional barriers among departments to strengthen working relationships and improve efficiency.
column12: Robert works in a large informational technology company that uses a matrix structure. Joanna is his manager in the programming department. Tristan leads the project that Robert is currently working on. Robert reports to which of these individuals?
column14: Both Joanna and Tristan.
column15: What does the organizational matrix structure focus on?
column17: The use of a strong hierarchical structure.
column18: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of a network organizational design structure?
column21: Which type of organizational design structure keeps the core functions of the business internal while outsourcing non-core functions to third parties?
column23: Network

column9: What's another name for a divisional organizational structure?
column11: U-form
column12: Which of the following best describes a divisional organizational structure?
column14: An organization that is divided into semi-autonomous units
column15: Which of the following is not an advantage of a divisional structure?
column17: It's always cheap
column18: Which one of the following companies was one of the first to use of a divisional structure?
column21: Which one of the following is not a disadvantage of a divisional structure?
column23: Divisions are semi-autonomous

column9: Sales and marketing, finance and accounting, customer service, and human resources are a few examples of groupings within which organizational design type?
column11: Divisional
column12: All of the following are traits of the simple organizational design structure, EXCEPT:
column14: High departmentalization
column15: Why are functional structures used by an organization?
column17: To have specialized work units that maximize functionality.
column18: Why is a divisional design structure used?
column20: To create several semi-autonomous units that focus on a narrow sector of business.
column21: How does having a top-level executive impact divisional structures?
column23: It makes them more successful by ensuring that someone who has authority is available at all times.

column9: Why should you NOT generalize when linking elements of organizational structure to employee performance and satisfaction?
column11: It is okay to generalize when linking elements of organizational structure and employee performance and satisfaction.
column12: The structure of an organization can impact the organization's members in which of the following ways?
column14: All of the answers are correct.
column15: Which statement captures the downside to a high level of work specialization?
column17: A high degree of work specialization can lead to a low level of job satisfaction by some individual members of an organization.
column18: Of the six elements of organizational structure, how many can be shown to be consistently tied to employee performance and behavior?
column21: Which statement is NOT true regarding centralization in organizational structure?
column23: A high level of centralization results in participative decision-making among organizational members, which is positively linked to a high level of job satisfaction.
column24: Why is structure so important to an organization?
column26: Organizational structure helps to define roles and expectations for employees.

column9: How does a mechanistic structure differ from an organic structure?
column11: The organic structure is usually far less formal and departmentalized
column12: How does organizational strategy affect organizational structure?
column14: An organizational strategy is crucial to developing and implementing a viable organizational structure, An organizational strategy is crucial to developing and implementing a viable organizational structure
column15: A small business sells computers directly to customers. It does not incorporate excessive innovation and spends little on advertising. The environment at the company is very informal and could best be described as organic. Why is this NOT a common cost minimization strategy?
column17: There usually is a strong hierarchy in a cost minimization strategy
column18: An IT company focuses on copying and mass-producing computer hardware that is similar to successful devices developed by companies that follow an innovation strategy. Which of the following structures would best suit the IT company's strategy?
column20: Both the mechanistic and organic structure
column21: Why does an organic structure work best for an innovation strategy?
column23: This combination is not ideal; a formal structure would be a lot better for an innovation strategy

column9: In a centralized organization, policies and procedures are usually _____.
column11: diverse
column12: Span of Control is:
column14: the number of employees a manager can feasibly oversee
column15: How can centralized authority be a disadvantage?
column17: Decision-making can be very slow.
column18: How are orders transmitted in a centralized organization?
column21: Marcy gets orders to work on clients from her supervisor. When her supervisor is away and an important decision needs to be made, Marcy is authorized to make it. Marcy works _____.
column23: under decentralized authority

column9: Which of the following is synonymous with work specialization?
column11: Division of labor
column12: _____ refers to an organization's practice of assigning individual tasks into separate jobs.
column14: Work specialization
column15: Fred has chosen to implement work specialization at his expanding recycling company. What could he do to prevent a negative outcome?
column17: Develop methods to facilitate clear communication and build a sense of teamwork to prevent isolation
column18: Which of the following businesses would BEST benefit from work specialization?
column21: What is one potential outcome for an organization utilizing work specialization?
column23: Low morale due to limited interaction and collaboration

column9: Amy works in a company that has had a very casual environment for years. Now she has to sign her name both electronically and on paper prior to submitting any work and she feels that this change is completely unnecessary. Identify which of the following factors motivates her resistance to change:
column11: Lack of understanding what the future of these changes could bring
column12: Approximately 70 workers are employed at an IT firm called Johnson Incorporated. All of these workers are used to checking in with their supervisors five minutes before starting to work. In case an employee has a good idea, he doesn't have to worry about channels but can go straight to the CEO. The environment is very casual here. Why are these things examples of organizational culture?
column14: Because they reflect basic shared norms, beliefs and values of Johnson Incorporated.
column15: Which of the following is a useful tactic after deciding on a change?
column17: Involve staff in every step of decision-making
column18: Which of the following does an organization have full control over?
column20: The way a production process of a particular product is conducted
column21: An advisory board of a multinational company is trying to assess the main challenges that the company will have to overcome in the next five years. Amongst them, they have listed these: dismissing fears regarding globalization, trying to predict the fluctuations of the stock market, and keeping up with the technological requirements of the industry. What do all of these goals have in common?
column23: They are all examples of external changes.

column9: Why did Senge include personal mastery as one of his five disciplines?
column11: Because systems thinking can only be done once all of the individual employees have met all of their personal goals
column12: Which of these is NOT considered to be a benefit of becoming a learning organization?
column14: Promotes additional competition between internal employees
column15: Sam's Gear is a very traditional organization that manufactures camping equipment. Stellar Trek is a learning organization that also manufactures camping equipment. How might the two organizations vary in their approaches to an economic slow down in a way that CLEARLY demonstrates their organizational difference?
column17: Sam's Gear might continue manufacturing their best selling line of gear, while Stellar Trek might create a new line in response to changing consumer desires.
column18: Which of these answers BEST describes a learning organization?
column20: One in which organizational members are constantly learning from everything they do.
column21: How did Peter Senge help to popularize the idea of learning organizations?
column23: Through the publication of his book, The Fifth Discipline

column9: Lauren held a staff appreciation luncheon to inform her employees that existing clients' feedback on phase one of the new skincare system and pricing structure was overwhelmingly positive. Why is this an example of the sixth step of the change model, generate short-term wins?
column11: The manager publicly recognized employees with evidence their efforts are paying off
column12: Which of the following does NOT occur during step seven of Kotter's 8-step change model, consolidate gains to produce more change?
column14: Creating a team tasked with kick starting the change
column15: Which of the following actions would a manager take to empower broad-based action?
column17: Immediately address any barriers to keep the change process moving
column18: Why would an organization use Kotter's eight-step change model?
column20: To implement transformational change in the organization
column21: As CEO of his company, Mack seeks to use Kotter's 8-step change model to make a comprehensive organizational change to improve efficiency and boost the company's sagging profits. As part of the first step, he outlines a program he believes will revive the business in six to nine months. What aspect of the first step in the change model did he miss?
column23: He didn't foster a sense of urgency by helping employees realize that their jobs depend on their support of the changes

column9: In which of the following steps of Kotter's change model does management take time to paint a picture of what the organization's future will look like after the change has taken place?
column11: Consolidate gains to produce more change
column12: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves inspiring the necessary teamwork, ideas, and eagerness to make sacrifices relating to the change?
column14: Establish a sense of urgency
column15: During a major change initiative, management discovers that there is not enough understanding about the change itself and there is a lack of strong project management for the change. These types of obstacles would be dealt with in which of the following steps in Kotter's change model?
column17: Empowering broad-based action
column18: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves monitoring the acceptance of change and how well the organizational culture is adapting to the change?
column20: Anchor changes in the organization's culture
column21: Which of the following steps in Kotter's change model involves the change leader selecting and recruiting a team of individuals who will be capable of carrying out the change?
column23: Create the guiding coalition

column9: When stating the problem, it is important to:
column11: define future state only
column12: The first step in the force field analysis involves:
column14: stating the problem
column15: Driving forces are interested in:
column17: causing change
column18: Equilibrium is:

column24: Resistant forces:
column26: want to maintain the status quo

column9: Which stage of Lewin's model is used to create an awareness of how the status quo, or current level of acceptability, is hindering the organization in some way?
column11: Unfreezing

column14: Cementing
column15: During which stage of Lewin's model does reinforcing, stabilizing, and solidifying the new state after the change occur?
column17: Refreezing

column21: Which of the three stages make up Lewin's change model?
column23: Unfreezing, changing, refreezing

column9: Identify the business situation that will require an urgent change plan.
column11: The profit for HS company Ltd has decreased by 75% over the last 2 years.
column12: Which of these steps in the planned change process provides the objective or expectation of how a change will respond to whatever forces are driving the need for change?
column14: Develop change goals.
column15: How is the effectiveness of a change plan evaluated?
column17: By comparing the actual results against change goals to determine if the goals were achieved.
column18: Why is it desirable to appoint a change agent who is outside of the company?
column20: Because of the expertise and unique abilities that the change agent possess to drive change.
column21: Which of these steps in the planned change process puts the change plan into action?
column23: Implement the change.

column9: Which of the following is NOT a reason why employees resist change?
column11: They fear the status quo.
column12: How does organizational change impact a company?
column14: It does not make any changes, the changes impact the environment rather than the company.
column15: A large company is trying to implement an organizational change. The company is trying to switch from primarily door-to-door operations to internet sales. They feel the changing marketplace requires that they adapt and have invested over $10,000,000 into this transition. The company's labor unions have organized strikes and the workers are threatening to resign. Why did the change fail?
column17: Because the employees refuse to accept the change.
column18: How do external factors differ to internal factors?
column20: Internal factors are things like company policies or procedures, while external factors are things over which the company has very little influence on.
column21: A company is trying to force a change by letting their employees know they will be fired if the organizational change fails. They have also stated that the entire change must happen at once and have tried to communicate to the employees why the change was necessary. Did company management perform any of the right steps to overcome employee opposition to change?
column23: Company management tried to communicate the importance of the change to the employees.

column9: An IT company has decided that you no longer need to report to your supervisor before you make minor changes to software. Instead, you can now simply post the minor change on the company's community forum. Why is this an example of a structural change?
column11: Because it leads to better communication within the company

column14: Internal

column17: It should be monitored, and at times even the company's fundamental approach to business may be altered due to it.
column18: ABC Corp wants to improve employee performance, skills, attitudes, behavior and loyalty to the organization. What type of changes should they make?
column21: How does process change differ from strategic change?
column23: Process change is based on everyday operations, while strategic focuses on long-term goals.

column9: Which term describes the act of monitoring the organization's internal and external environments for early signs that a change may be needed?
column11: Environmental evaluation
column12: ABC Company manufactures various electronic items for sale in an online market. Recently, sales have dropped off and, after doing some research, the management team discovers that an upstart company is selling to a portion of ABC's long-standing customer base. In response, ABC's management elects to launch a new marketing strategy to rebuild its customer base. This action represents _____.
column14: changing for the external environment
column15: The following are representative of an organization's external environment EXCEPT _____.
column17: the ability to attract good employees
column18: The following are representative of an organization's internal environment EXCEPT the _____.
column21: To remain competitive in the marketplace, Mary and her leadership team conducted a SWOT analysis to develop new strategies. This analysis could include studying all of the following EXCEPT:
column23: tactics within the company's external environment

column11: remember that department management gets the credit when quotas are achieved.
column12: Why did Japanese business leaders feel the need to develop and implement the process known as TQM?
column14: Its economy was a shambles after World War II and needed rebuilding.
column15: When a university implements TQM to improve the quality of classroom instruction, which of these would be an output?
column17: student achievement on standardized tests
column18: The head of Acme Tools and Plumbing, Jordy McClellan, decided to solve a customer complaint problem by conducting company-wide customer service training. The goals were to improve the process and transform the culture of the company to revolve around serving customers. Which aspect of Total Quality Management (TQM) did Mr. McClellan use?
column21: The foundation of Total Quality Management (TQM) is based upon a continuous thought process that involves the entire purchase experience. Which of the following is NOT part of that process?
column23: Company profits

column9: When looking at the external environment, companies typically look at
column11: Technology, politics, competitors, economy
column12: Define contingency planning.
column14: If you want to run a business effectively, for any period of time, you must be prepared for emergencies or disruptions that relate to how your business runs.
column15: Mary is an analyst for a bank. Every month she reviews company reports and goes online to search for potential threats and opportunities that may affect the bank in the future. Mary is performing which aspect of contingency planning?
column17: Environmental searching
column18: A fruit packing company in Florida makes plans for what it will do in the event a hurricane strikes. This is called _____
column21: Which of these would be part of the implementation of contingency management at XYZ Corp.
column23: Using Vroom's expectancy theory to motivate employees

column9: Which of the following products is most likely produced in a company that utilizes a closed system?
column11: A car
column12: How does a failure in one part impact the system as a whole?
column14: It renders the rest of the system unusable.
column15: What does entropy cause in a business system?
column17: A discord or a lack of predictability, a gradual decline into disorder.
column18: Why do companies mostly use the same system throughout the world?
column20: Because the system is part of how the company functions.
column21: The board of an IT company is discussing their new business strategy to increase sales by 30%, although they are satisfied with the current number of products they have. Based on customer surveys that shows a demand for a longer battery life for their top product, an expensive mobile phone, they have added a much stronger battery to their product. Why is this an example of an open system?
column23: Because they are paying attention to customer demands.

column9: How does the operations management of today differ from the time of Henry Ford and his assembly line?
column11: It is a lot more complex today as companies used to be focused only on production, while today they are more oriented towards the quality of the product.
column12: Which of the following is relevant in regards to capital requirements?
column14: How much machinery you need to implement a project.
column15: Jane is a company CEO. She heard rumors that the accounting division is very unproductive because many of her employees do not have their talents utilized in the best manner, and there is constant infighting. What aspect should Jane focus on to improve the productivity there?
column17: Human capital
column18: John's company is starting a new product line to increase their revenue, and make themselves more famous in the general public. They are trying to make the production process as efficient as possible by analyzing every step and making sure it doesn't waste needless time. Why is this an example of process planning?
column20: Because they are taking it from a strategic approach by positioning themselves well in the eye of the public.
column21: Which of the following is NOT an integral part of business?
column23: Controlling

column9: What is classic management theory?
column11: Finding the best possible way for employees to perform their tasks
column12: A manager in an IT company is trying to decide whether to focus on producing very expensive computers or cheap laptops at affordable prices. Before making his decision, he is interested in knowing more about the analysis of data and the past, present and future trends of both the market and his company. Which of the following should he use to make his decision?
column14: Management information systems
column15: Behavioral aspects are considered in _____.
column17: both classic management theory and the quantitative school of management
column18: Which of the following is considered only by the quantitative school of management?
column20: Analysis of data using statistical models and simulations
column21: The top level of management of a company which produces old-fashioned furniture is not satisfied with its productivity. It has hired a consultant who specializes in systems management theory to take a look at the manufacturing process. A factory worker has described the process as: taking a quality piece of pine or maple and subjecting it to a process where specialised equipment is used to transform it into a table which they then ship to the customer and request a survey response of his satisfaction about the product. Which of the following is the output of the process?
column23: The table

column9: Which option best matches the systems approach?
column11: Focus on data, processes and products that, when put together, make a whole unit.
column12: Which option best matches the contingency approach?
column14: Use different approaches or systems for different situations
column15: Which of these choices best matches the quantitative approach?
column17: Use statistics and mathematical techniques to analyze data.
column18: How is the quantitative approach better for management, as opposed to the systems approach?
column20: Neither approach is better or worse, as each has a place and situation where it might be better or worse. Additionally, they can be merged and blended.
column21: An approach solely reliant on statistics and data is _____
column23: Quantitative

column9: Mary allows her employees plenty of leeway in how they do their jobs and expects them to motivate themselves to be high achievers. She sets the standard by coming in early and working as hard as they do. The self fulfilling prophecies predict that her employees _____
column11: will eventually burn out because of the rigorous work schedule she has set for them.
column12: Joe thinks that his workers hate their job and only come to work to earn their paychecks. However, he is satisfied with their creativity and imagination when they work on projects. Is Joe a typical Theory X manager?
column14: No, because he believes in their creativity and imagination.
column15: Which of the following is credited with the development of the Theory X and Theory Y?
column17: Douglas McGregor
column18: Rebecca runs a research department with specific goals for new product ideas. She lets employees work on their own new product ideas every Friday with little supervision. Rebecca is practicing _____ management.
column21: Mike is a Theory X manager. Which of these does he assume about his employees ?
column23: They would rather be told what to do instead of directing themselves

column9: What does a manager need to provide in order to satisfy his employees' physiological needs?
column11: A suitable working team and a team leader that will be able to recognize the problems in the company environment and positively act to solve these problems.
column12: Which of the following is necessary in order to satisfy Maslow's safety needs?
column14: Having job security and receiving a salary
column15: Which of Maslow's five needs can a manager fulfill by providing challenging work, inviting employees to participate in decision-making, and giving them flexibility and autonomy in their jobs?
column17: Self-actualization needs
column18: Each of the following answer choices represents the fulfillment of one of Maslow's needs. Identify the answer choice that represents achieving the HIGHEST need on Maslow's Hierarchy pyramid.
column20: Tom started working at 8:00. At 8:15, his team-leader told him that the work he had recently done was excellent and he said if Tom kept up with the good work he would surely be promoted very soon.
column21: You are working for a large international company. One of your project proposals raised the revenue of your department by 5%. Your boss said, You are an exemplary employee and your work ethic and efficiency is at such a level that the entire company should strive towards it. Which of Maslow's five needs would your boss's comment satisfy?
column23: Esteem needs

column9: How would a modern day manager best implement what was learned in the Hawthorne Studies?
column11: Provide additional benefits to employees including on site daycare
column12: How did the Hawthorne Study of five women in a bank writing room change perceptions about what motivates workers?
column14: They showed that motivation improved when workers were shown attention by observers.
column15: Which two researchers are most commonly associated with the second Hawthorne Studies experiment?
column17: Mayo and Roethlisberger
column18: Which term describes a psychological phenomenon in which participants in behavioral studies change their behavior or performance in response to being observed?
column21: How did the Hawthorne Studies affect thinking about management theory?
column23: Social and human relations aspects became part of management theory.

column9: Which of the following is a factor that can help increase employee motivation?
column11: Positive feedback and appraisals.
column12: How does the theory of classical leadership management differ from the behavioral management theory?
column14: Classical leadership focused only on high production and efficiency, while behavioral management theory focuses on worker satisfaction.
column15: Which of the following is NOT an intrinsic motive for working?
column17: Salary
column18: Why was Mayo's Hawthorne experiment relevant to behavioral management theory?
column20: Because it proved that there was increased productivity if the workers felt the management was interested in their well-being.
column21: A manager is trying to motivate his employees because company productivity is declining. He decreases their benefits by 10%, and awards them tasks he knows they will find boring. Employees are told that their position is safe, and they can advance if they start working harder. He declares the only goal is increasing company revenue, and that common values are not important to the company. Which of these was a good move based on the behavioral management theory?
column23: Decreasing worker benefits by 10% in order to motivate them.

column9: Why was the neoclassical theory of management developed?
column11: Because classical theories were deficient by not accounting for the human side of production
column12: Which of these describes the focus of neoclassical management theory?
column14: the best way to motivate, structure, and support employees
column15: According to the Human Relations Movement, which of these would increase employee productivity?
column17: Making employees feel valued by taking care of their social and human relations needs
column18: According to Neoclassical Management Theory, managers are encouraged to do which of these?
column20: Create supportive social systems and facilitate the personal development of their workers
column21: How would a manager implement the ideas of the behavioral movement into her workplace?
column23: By rewarding the best employees with more responsibility and promotions

column9: What is the best reward an informal group can offer a new member?
column11: It is required to be on track for promotions and management opportunities.
column12: Effective organizations, according to Barnard, are those that _____.
column14: accomplish their goals quickly
column15: Marge, a manager, makes it a point to join in with the informal group's lunchtime conversation at least once per week. She lets them know they are valued and doing important work. Why is it important that Marge do this ?
column17: It will help get the informal group to accept her formal authority.
column18: Formal organizations are _____.
column20: structured by hierarchy, rules, and policies
column21: According to the acceptance theory, managers have authority when _____
column23: they can legitimately give orders and have a legitimate expectation that the orders will be carried out.

column9: How would Amy implement people oriented management in her beauty salon?
column11: By setting the weekly schedule jointly with her staff
